reviewText: This is without a doubt the best Sonic game in recent years. I have to say that if you are a Sonic fan, this is a must buy. I would say it's much better than Unleashed and a nice improvement over Colors. In this game, Sonic still has the boost feature from Unleashed and Colors as well as quick step, grind rail switching, and even some color powers from Colors. But the main feature of this Sonic game is that you have two Sonics now. The modern Sonic with all the tricks he's had from Adventure, Unleashed, etc. And the classic Sonic we've all known since the original trilogy. Story wise, it's ok. It's nothing too special. It does have a twist which I won't spoil, but this story pretty much only exists as an excuse to let us use classic Sonic in a newer game which is fine. Sonic's friends like Amy, Tails, Cream, Knuckles, etc are all there. But there only purpose is to be side characters. This is only about Sonic, but you can play as other characters with mods if you want. Moving on, this Sonic game is an anniversary type of game and it includes remastered versions of classic stages like the very first Green Hill, Sky Sanctuary, and others like Speed Highway. And you can fight past game bosses like Death Egg and Metal Sonic in HD and 3D for the first time! There's some others which I won't spoil, but just know that there aren't too many bosses. So you might end up disappoined if you were expecting a ton of bosses from the classic games or something. There's also missions for you to do after you beat the normal stages. But they're mostly optional so you can move on if you're not interested in all of them. I have to say that even if you have never played a Sonic game before that you should still give it a try. It's good, however, it isn't flawless. The game is pretty short and if you've played previous games like Unleashed and already know how to play, it's gonna take you a few hours at most to beat it. I beat it on my first playthrough. The upside though is that there's PLENTY of extra mods for you to play. The amount of hours I've put in are mainly due to mods like the Project Unleashed mod. Which is pretty much all of Sonic Unleashed's first day stages but with Generation's play style which is excellent. And there's even a mod for Sonic Colors' Tropical Resort stages which is also nice. Overall, I totally recommend it and I'd say that after beating the main game you should definitely add a lot of mods. But, if you don't plan on modding, just pick this game up on sale. 9/10
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Virtues
Sonic Generations is undeniable proof that a modern iteration of Sonic doesn't have to be bad. I find it odd that this style of game isn't treated as the new standard for Sonic games instead more of a one off" title. The mix of older and newer style Sonic gameplay (Act 1 & Act 2) works wonderfully. The achievements in this game are fairly balanced. There are a lot of cumulative achievements to work toward and even a few hidden achievements to uncover (or look up).

Pitfalls
When you think "Sonic" speed tends to come to mind pretty quickly. I often found that the speed aspect of this game feels much less important than precision and taking higher routes. I sometimes observed minor control issues in the Act 2 sections using a wireless Xbox360 controller. Although the control issues were slightly annoying they didn't seem like a consistent issue. With a little persistence they just presented a minor annoyance to the task(s) at hand.
I mentioned achievements earlier
date: currently the "Time Attacker" achievement is still a bit buggy and doesn't show your times on the top layer of the "ranking attack" mode. You can just make sure you do each one to completion. If you forget if you've finished one or not
recommended:
ranked attack > leaderboards > friends will show your username with a time if you've completed that level.

reviewText:
Allright, I purchased this game mostly because I heard that you get to play original Sonic 1 in it. So, yeah... After beating the act 1, I figured out that I should do it again, but now in 3d. And so I did and still nothig, so... I beat the game and finished most of the challanges in 2d and 3d, looking for the mistical Sonic 1 all around and couldn't find it anywhere. So, after spending several hours in my noble quest to be able to play Sonic 1 in PC without some sort of simulator, I gave up on my own logic and I went to consult with the oracle (Google), looking for clues of how to get to this point of the game where you'll be able to play Sonic 1... To find out, that you actually can't. Not on PC version, at least. So, yeah... That was pretty dissapointing.

And the game itself is allright, though there are just like... 9 levels and 3 bosses. 18 levels, if you take in count the 3d version of those and 4 bosses, if you count the final one. So, after you beat those, welcome to the challenges and stuff. But it's enjoyable to replay some of the levels, so it's allright. Not a big fan of 3d Sonic, though.

7/10.

reviewText:
Where do I start?
I own both PC and console versions, which says a lot.
This game is AMAZING, and in my opinion it's right beside Sonic 3 & Knuckles and Sonic Unleashed.  It have memorable levels from past Sonic games, as well as music. Classic Sonic feels a little bit off if you expect Genesis-physics, but Modern Sonic is spot on and it's just a blast running through a level!
There's not a lot of levels, but the ones that are there are very detailed colorful and you can replay them over and over. The modding community is pretty big too, which adds a nice replayability.
All in all Sonic fans, as well non Sonic fans will at least get some fun out of it.

reviewText:
Sonic Generations is the best way to acknowledge good Sonic games that doesn't involve playing the older good Sonic games. The PC version of Sonic Generations is a very solid port, with high framerate support, modding support and decent fast visuals. However, running mods such as the Unleashed Project require a decent modern CPU due to the relatively poor CPU porting. This also means that people with slower or less powerful processors may have some problems running busier levels, due to the games poor handling of multiple CPU threads. I did not encounter any framerate problems, but there is always going to be users who do encounter these issues, and my warning is simply ensure that you have a decent CPU. The gameplay itself blends the best of older Sonic, with modern stages built around the best ideas of Unleashed and Colours.

I've only played it with a controller, so I can't judge the PC controls. I can point out that there is sometimes some delay between the pressing of the button, and Sonic actually doing it sometimes. Besides these occasional problems, the game controls very solidly and I have no actual complaints involving the controls beside this small problem. Sonic also has some problems with precise movements in some levels due to speed and sometimes eratic camera movements. The game also sadly lacks in the number of main courses, which is a shame because everything that they've put in, both modern and classic are brilliant. Game length is instead lengthened by short challenges that are required for progression, or unlock bonus tracks on the soundtrack for use in the game levels. Sadly, these challenges aren't really that interesting to play compared to the actual main games levels, and even with this, the game comes out on the short side.

Visuals and port wise, graphical options are limited, but with mod support and game support for high resolution textures and shadows, the port works well most of the time. For the speed that Sonic moves at, the visuals are acceptable (and improvable with mods), and run at 60 FPS, something not available on the console versions.

Sound-wise, the game for the most part shines. It features many tracks from older Sonic games, most of them are remixed and sound really good. Voice acting is a bit strange, minor characters such as those from Sonic Heroes, or ones like Shadow sound really stupid, but the main characters are voiced fine. There are some issues with audio sychronisation that I've encountered and have been unable to ever replicate, such as out of sync audio or no sound in the cutscenes at all, then again, the only thing you miss in this case is cheesy writing. No gameplay affecting issues though in terms of sound. The soundtrack, although consisting mostly of remixes, is still a great soundtrack, probably being one of my favourites for the series.

Overall, its a good Sonic game in an age of disappointing Sonic games, probably my favourite in the series. It ends up being a bit too short, which is sad because awful Sonic games like Sonic 06 are many times longer than this for the average player. Despite that, I'd say it is worth getting, unless you really hate Sonic. This game does almost everything right, fast colourful visuals, a story that doesn't get in the way of the game and a good varied soundtrack.

And then there's mods, which help almost every game they exist for.

reviewText:
Absolutely. Buy this.

The classic Sonic mechanics aren't perfect but still very much enjoyable. The elemental shields return, which is always nice even though it's not mandatory to win.

The modern Sonic is where this game really shines : this game understands how a 3D Sonic should be played and offers the ultimate experience.

The PC version offers a 60 FPS experience which will make the levels even more enjoyable, and with the mods available plus the one coming later, you would miss a lot of fun with the Blue Blur if you didn't buy this.

If I had one tiny problem with this game it would be the last bossfight which is absolutely terrible & annoying. But you can still beat the boss once you get used to the awkward controls of this last battle. Plus, one bad bossfight versus tons of fun levels & other bossfights ? This game is an absolute winner.

Very enjoyable from start to finish; I remembered all of the stages and I'm really interested in getting the handheld version as well, due to my love for the handheld levels too. As much as I like Modern and Classic Sonic controls, I feel most at home back in Sonic Adventure 2. With my 80 some lives. XD

Ultimately, 7/10. I had fun despite getting game overs (I shouldn't have died as many times as I did. I REALLY despise that sidestep nuisance. Classic Sonic was easiest and most fun to play.)

reviewText: This is probably my favorite Sonic game of the last 15 years. It's not something I plan to go back to and doesn't get visited near annually like 3&Knuckles, but I still enjoyed it a lot. It improved on the few things I liked about Unleashed and Colors and the added PC benefits of a rock solid framerate and higher resolution makes it more of a spectacle to play.\n\nI don't have the metrics or straight comparisons to validate this, but Generations felt a bit slower to me compared to Unleashed in the 3D sections. Either that or the zones were designed with Sonic's movement in mind more. While Unleashed felt like a game that rewards rote memorization and simply has too much speed" for the sake of speed

reviewText:
Although I didn't really get to enjoy the classic, shorter, fatter and mute Sonic in the earlier days as much as I had liked to as a child -- I had only played a few titles -- this game definitely makes up for it. Sonic Generations is an extremely fast-paced platformer that definitely pleases fans that had awaited for this release. Both modern Sonic and classic, original Sonic team up in hopes to save the world from an evil shadow-thing. At least that's what I have gathered so far.

Gameplay mechanics change throughout the game frequently between Acts. In the first Act of any stage you play as classic, mute Sonic along with the classic gameplay seen in the original. In Act 2 stages you play as modern Sonic.

Much can be said about this game so I'll sum it up: This has to be the best Sonic game I've played ever alongside Sonic and All Stars Racing: Transformed. I'm not far yet in Sonic Generations however. After I had seen the epic trailer for the game I knew I would have to pick it up. I am not disappointed.

I wish I had the time to write up a full review but I don't. I can only describe this game in few words in hopes of helping you get this game.

reviewText: This is SEGA's love letter to fans that were waiting for the time when Sonic The Hedgehog returned to his roots and had a great sense of speed, Sonic Generations is probably the best 3D Sonic game to be released since Sonic Adventure 2. In this wonderful game you play as both Classic Sonic and Modern Sonic, racing through stages from the blue hedgehog's past thanks to time travel, yeah the plot isn't really that great or isn't suspensful in anyway possible it's just an excuse to have 2 Sonic's on screen and give SEGA, the chance to revisted old worlds such as Green Hill Zone, Chemical Plant including some of the modern stages that have been completely remade, some for the better i'm looking at you Crisis City.\n\nThere is a lot of music in the game and it's fantastic the stage music is great both different for Modern and Classic Sonic, they also included various theme songs from different games and give you the choice to choose which song you want playing on a stage, once you've unlocked the tracks via getting red rings which I highly recommend you collect there is a lot of extra unlockables, though it's a shame you can't play as other characters but that can be done with mods on the PC version this game has a very active modding community so it's worth purchasing on PC and if your a really big fan of Sonic the Hedgehog, if you are then you'll get a kick out of this!.

reviewText:
Sonic and pals are throwing a super cool nostalgia party, and you're invited! How fun! Chilli dogs, drinks, and music galore! Everything starts out just dandy as our favorite hedgehog reflects on his past triumphs in the good old days. You can't help but gush over how much fun is in the air. You were there! You remember how great things were back in the day!

As Sonic goes on, you note several inconsistencies in his retellings of what went on in the 2000s. He's a little buzzed. You were there, and you know those things didn't happen as cool as he's making it seem but he tells it so well that you can't help but be entertained! Eventually you notice our hero's speech get slurrier and harder to understand by the time he's talking about the latter half of the decade, and then all hell breaks loose. Sonic's become heavily inebriated and is thrashing about violently, screaming SPIKE! ROCKEEEET!" at the top of his lungs.

You're trying your best to placate him
recommended: and his friends are about as helpless as you are at stopping him. Sonic suddenly stops what he's doing and takes a seat
hoursPlayed: beckoning you all towards him. He begins to talk about the time he and his past self faced off against Dr. Robotnik and HIS past self while they were piloting some weird time monster. Chills run down your spine as he describes horrors of which you'd never wish upon even the most obnoxious of talking animals.\n\nAfter an eerie silence sets in
voteText: Sonic erupts from his seat in a drunken stupor and defecates on the floor. He turns to look at you with his tearful
helpfulPercent: bloodshot eyes and yells "they said my future was gonna be great!" before jumping out of the window and sprinting off into the wilderness
votesTotal: you can't help but to mutter to yourself that he wasn't always like this
votesFunny: and that one day
commentsCount:
one day he'll be having great adventures once again just like the good old days. Like the good old days...



In the meantime hey this game is wonderful fun until you get to the Colors stages and final boss which are total crap 8/10 would spindash again make sure you get the good mods for it too"

reviewText:
Overall, Sonic Generations is gud enough for yer all sanic player who likes both the oldschool sanic games and the modern one. This gaem has a nostalgic feelz in it, because you'll play through remake of old stage from sanic's games. Some of the bgm are remixes, but you can change it once you get the music through challenge stage (not all bgm included). So, this game is worth to buy

PROS
+2fast4u
+It's Sanic
+2 playable character (Sonic and Sonic)
+Classic and modern stage
+Both 2D and 3D level
+Remixes BGM
+Collectible and achievement farming included
+Classic story
+The stage are beautifully created
+Working good with wooden pc like mine (Even though you must tweaked a bit)
+Epic boss fight
+You can change the bgm used in stage/boss fight
+Beautifully rendered cutscene
+It's not sanic boom

CONS
-The stage are recycled from the old games, so no new stages
-Remixes BGM

reviewText:
A time paradox many people love.  I can simply summarize this game as a vision of nostalgia reflecting on where Sonic came from and how far Sonic has come.

What I think is awesome is the ability to play through stages that are reminiscent of the games of yester-year as Modern Sonic, yet being able to play through the games of today as Classic Sonic.  Really nice experience.   However, the final battle is truly lacking....

Downsides?  I've experienced slowdown during cutscenes which ruins the voice synchronization of Sonic and Tails.  There are also some moments during the game where the controls will be unresponsive during a few critical moments.  Pits Ahoy!!!!


This made me remember how good Sonic used to be.  Very nice experience.

reviewText:
First off, I played some Sonic Adventure (1 and 2), Sonic Heroes and Shadow The Hedgehog and loved all of those (Yes even shadow) when I was little. I thought they were amazing, but I never really played the old ones so I wasn't that much of a Sonic fan. Just recently I got this and played this, and HOLY ♥♥♥♥.

I thought this was more than anything Just a lot of fan service disguised of a game. And yes, maybe it is, but I have to say this game is AMAZING. I didn't even play the classic Sonic games, so I can't really say the nostalgia applies to me. Even so, the 2D levels, which I was kinda afraid of at first, are extremely fun and work wonderfully with the playstyle. They blend with some 3D sections, which are also great. Controlling Sonic in those feels tighter than in any other Sonic game I played.

Gameplay aside, the presentation in this game is mind blowing, both music wise and visually. The visuals are stunning, everything is moving, changing; it feels great. The music is also really good. The song of City Escape is still on my mind.

And, for the story, well, don't expect one. Is really simple. Is mostly an excuse for remastering levels and having the two Sonics. But it works wonders, so hey, this is not a problem in my book.

Another bad thing I could say, is that the game is short. I played only 3 hours (didn't finish it yet), and you can blaze through the stages. However there are a lot of side missions and stuff to do. Also, I heard that there are mods. So I'm not really worried for that.


Anyway, in conclusion, this game is Just great. There's a lot of Sonic games I didn't play, but I think it'll be hard to top this one. The game is a blast to play, to look at, to hear. Is pretty much perfect for what it is: a celebration for having Sonic around for so long. I have no doubt that if you played other games on the franchise first you will enjoy it A LOT more (City Escape, GOD), but even if you're not a die hard fan, this is probably one of the best Sonic games you can get. So yeah, buy it.

TL;DR game is great; sonic is fast; buy it

reviewText:
So my first proper review, and what way to start it off with one of the best Sonic games ever, even if it is simply a load of past stages recreated.
The cutscenes are greatly improved from the Xbox 360 version, no longer looking pixilated, well for me anyway. It also runs at a very nice and plesent 60 FPS, making Sonic and his vibrant surroundings look georgous no matter what. The game as a whole looks fantasic as it is, from the cheerful rolling hills of Green Hill Zone, to the gritty and action-packed Crysis City.
The stages are so much fun. Each course is littered with secrets and alternate routes that I am still discovering every time I go back to shave precious milliseconds off your high scores. They really are a blast to play and feel unique from one another but not too gimmicky, which Sonic games have felt like in the past. As well as stages we each fight a classic boss at the end of the Era, either being the final boss of a previous game or a rival character (wait, how is Silver here?). The rivals are cool and interesting ideas, and well executed, along with the other bosses. I would have to say my favourite rival is Shadow, it feels just so... right, and it's an amazing update to fight in Sonic Adventure 2. I also love the Death Egg Robo as one of the bosses, all it's phases are just awesome and mix up the battle.
But obviously, the highlight of this game is the music, as expected. I love every single one of the remixes (errr... minus Planet Wisp and another Open Your Heart remix, they got butchered) and is my favourite soundtrack next to Sonic 3 & Knuckles and Sonic Adventure 2. From the incredible violins in Rooftop Run to the tears of manliness I cry when I hear City Escape for the 7 billionth time.  Just take some time to listen to it, you'll love it.
However, having said that, there are some minor complaints. The game as a whole is a bit short, it'll take you roughly 2-3 hours to complete and even less if your a veteran of the series. The Red Rings add a little more time to 7-9 hours and are a nice reward and incentive for you to discover and explore the stages and it's many routes. Also, the game is very easy. For me anyway, I got most S-Ranks first time. I also find myself going back to Modern Sonic more than Classic Sonic, despite so many people yarning for his return.
Overall, this game is amazing, for what there is of it. It may be short, and easy, but if your just looking for some high-speed-nostalgia-trippin'-rocking-beats-blue-burred blast, this is the game for you. A great way to celebrate Sonic's 20th anniversary and a perfect example that the hedgehog is still on top.
9/10

reviewText:
This game is great for Sonic fans old and new. I don't suggest buying this unless you have a pretty good gaming PC, as if it's just a casual computer you'll get a very low FPS (at least in my case that's what happened)

Positive:
+ The graphics are good
+ The story is alright, I think they could have done a better job, but it's great for being able to re-play old levels!
+ Mods, there's a lot of mods, and with another program, they're very easy to install.

Negative:

Other than that it's great, the developers did a really good job with this game, I totally recommend this for anyone who is already a Sonic fan, or is interested in the games.

After getting a new computer that can run this game amazingly, it is one of the best games I've ever played. 10/10

reviewText: Sonic and I being the same age, I am literally a life long fan, in two senses of the phrase. Very rarely has a game met my expectations as well as this game has. The gameplay is basically right out of Sonic Colors and the day time levels of Unleashed, so basically, the best 3D gameplay the franchise has had, with the sidescrolling gameplay being excellent as well. Wrap that up with two versions of one fan favorite level from nine Sonic games, as well as two new versions of each stages song, and I'm a happy camper. The levels retain all the energy and life they started with, with their own new additional twists, and the remixed songs are great. Even better is that cool little surprises where things outside of the original stages being redone will be referenced, such as the Sonic Adventure 1 hotel making an appearance in that game's given stage. This is a must buy for Sonic fans, and I'd even suggest it for people that are just curious about the franchise.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Sonic generations... what can I say, I was a big fan of Sonic games on PC in my youth and tried coming back to try the new games in the series. Sadly they were incredibly frustrating, incredibly buggy or just plain painful to play, Sonic generations is the first attempt to fix this.

The game can be broken up into Act1 (Classic Sonic), Act2 (Modern Sonic), Boss battles (each boss fight has a particular Sonic mandatory) and finally challenges for each Sonic. Let's go over each of them:

Classic Sonic (Act1 of each stage): Classic Sonic is the sonic of our past with a bit of a modern twist on it. The levels are straight forward, simple to play and good fun. If you have played any Sonic game from the 90's then you will have no worries here. The only thing that will grab you is the occasional 3D feel it gives off.

Modern Sonic (Act2 of each stage): Modern Sonic is the character most associated with the bad Sonic games in a 3D world. Sonic generations gives modern Sonic high speed levels to play in at the start and it's a lot of fun seeing how fast you can clear a level. The later stages though are annoying and painful to say the least, it's at this point I started wished I could play the full game with just classic Sonic.

Boss fights: The bosses are a really strong point to this game, they are fun to play, the tactics aren't too hard and both Sonics feel really good to play as.

Challenges: Here is where the game really free falls to a large extent. At the beginning the challenges are really fun to play be it trying to out race a doppelganger or just use your skate/snow board to finish a level is great fun. Once those are done though it feels like the developers ran out of ideas and just made stuff up, the later challenges have you trying to collect rings in a fixed time (2 things I hate, collection duty with a time trial). Another one is hitting the level end sign to the end of the level or depending on side characters to help you, these are annoying and frustrating to say the least.

If you are a Sonic fan you should give it a go, for everyone else wait for 50% or more off.

reviewText:
After some flops in the Sonic franchise (Sonic '06, Secret Rings, etc.), this game gets the series back on it's feet, and then it does a backflip and wins the World Cup. In other words, it's really great.

Story: Sonic from the past and present, along with their friends, get sucked into a limbo of sorts. After playing through a few areas, the two meet up. Then they decide they need to help save his friends and return the locations back to the real world- erm, the games real world, the sonic world, Mobius. It's a really good plot. it engrosses the player, it does take a bit to start up however. It's still, nontheless, a great storyline. [Score: 8.5/10]

Presentation: The graphics for this game are amazing. I originally bought it for the PS3, then recently bought it on Steam as part of a Collection of Sonic games. The PC graphics are undoubtedly better, although you can't hate the PS3's graphics on this game either. The game looks great. [Score 10/10]

Gameplay: There are 2 Styles of gameplay, Classic Sonic, and Modern Sonic. Classic Sonic goes back to the roots of the series. Sidescrolling bliss. Modern Sonic goes with the style of playthrough from daytime Unleashed and all of Colors (save for the double jump). Not too much to say about it. Tight controls, high-speed gameplay, it's all really great. [Score 10/10]

Level Design: This game was released for Sonic's 20th Anniversary. This is probably why it remixes old stages from other games. The only new stage is the final boss. However, this isn't a bad thing, far from it! This is one of the many reasons this game was so successful. There are 5 stage types, Regular Stage Act 1, Regular Stage Act 2, Mini-Bosses, Bosses, and the final boss. The Regular Stages are for Classic, and Modern, respectively. The Minibosses are unlocked halfway through 3 of the 4 areas of the main hub. They are just reimaginings of older versions of bosses from older games. We have Metal Sonic from Sonic CD, Shadow from Sonic Adventure 2, and Silver from Sonic '06 (but acctually playable). The Boss fights, with the exception of the last one, are throwbacks to other final (or close to final) bosses from other games. These include: Death Egg Robot from Sonic 2, Perfect Chaos from Sonic Adventure, and Egg Dragoon from Sonic Unleashed. Each fight is really solid. The Final boss is Time Eater, in which Modern and Classic sonic both go super and you take them out in a way similar to The True Final Boss in Sonic 3 & Knuckles' The Doomsday Zone. My only real gripe is that Time Eater is a little bit unforgiving, it took me a few tries to beat it. That or I just suck. [Score 9.5/10]

Music: Along with the stages, the music is remixed from their respected stages (again, with the exception of the final boss), they are all really good. Some of my favorites include Death Egg Robot, Chemical Plant Zone Act 1, Metal Sonic, and my personal favorite, Time Eater. [Score 10/10 (although I wish it could be higher)]

Total Score: 48/50

Thank you for taking the time to read this, and Good Night.

reviewText: This game is amazing. whether you play it in 40 frames per second or 60, the game looks and feels great. The game already has a ton of content, and there's tons of free mods for it including: a real hedgehog texture(it only works on modern Sonic but still looks both cool and hillarious), solo ports of levels from Colors, Adventure 1&2, even a level from the almost forgotten Shadow the Hedgehog, and most impressively a port of more than half of the daytime stages from Sonic unleashed. reviewText:
Sonic Generations is surprisingly good considering it's, well a Sonic Game. It seems Sega can still produce a Sonic game these days that I'd actually come back to several times and have fun. Though harldy perfect, the usual game ruining bugs are largely absent and controlling Sonic and Classic Sonic is surprisingly easy. Occasionally you seem to fall out of the world due to some bizzare glitch in the matixs sending you careening left off a upwards vertical path plus the odd falling through the earth glitch as well. Despite obvious flaws, it's well polished, fun and a great buy for anyone looking to feel a bit nostaligic.

Sonic Generations offers two modes, Modern and Classic where you control the respective hendgehog. Modern Sonic is a blend of super sonic running sections a-la Sonic Adventure and 2D platforming sections based off of the last few titles. Classic Sonic however goes back the series roots on the Genesis and focuses striclty on 2D momentum based platforming.

Missions, a Pinball minigame and hidden red rings offer a good amount of replayablity. Sadly no Chao Garden.

reviewText:
This is a mild recommendation. I was a big Sonic fan as a kid, so this game has a huge nostalgia value for me. The 2D Sonic levels feel great, the 3D levels are usually pretty good, and hearing a lot of the classic music from the games being remixed is fantastic.

But I was a little disappointed in this game, too. I wasn't expecting to finish the game in 6 hours. That feels REALLY short to me, particularly since the game's currently selling for $30 at full price. (I, luckily, got it on sale.) There are a lot of optional challenges which I mostly haven't done, but I didn't feel like the gameplay was compelling enough to make me want to.

And in the 3D levels I stumbled across some of the flaws that have plagued the series since the switch to 3D--glitches (one time I fell through the floor and died), a wonky camera (which is REALLY frustrating when you go fast) and occasionally frustrating controls (a lot of times I didn't home in on an enemy with my homing attack when I thought for sure that it should've worked--I'm not sure if it was a glitch or if I was just unclear on how it should work but either way, it was frustrating).

I ended up feeling pretty luckwarm on this game, which was really disappointing considering all the praise I've been hearing about it. It DID tickle my nostalgia so I'm giving it a rec for that--the game sets out what it wants to do, pay homage to the Sonic series. If you're a fan and that's what you're wanting, pick it up. Otherwise I find this hard to recommend--there's a lot of better platformers out there on Steam nowadays. At the very least, I'd wait for this game to go on sale rather than paying full-price.

reviewText:
Sonic Generations represents a return to form for Sonic. While recent 3D sonic games have been... lackluster, Sonic Generations has Sonic finally hitting his stride. Sonic and Classic Sonic are the only playable characters, each handling the levels in different ways.

Sonic finally controls well, and though there are frustrating moments, the game is still overall enjoyable.

I found it enjoyable to replay levels that I had previously beaten to try to get a better time or find all the secrets, something that will take quite a while.

Anybody who considers, or has considered themselves a Sonic fan owes it to themselves to play this game. It's a bit short, but sweet.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: For those of you who have played Sonic the Hedgehog and enjoyed it, you will love this game. For those of you who probably avoided teh Sonic games, I suggest getting the demo. This game is great, and runs remarkably smooth. The game has a mere 18 levels over 9 different worlds. Not particularly amazing, but those levels provide tons of replay value as you attempt to get all the S ranks.\n\nClassic Sonic is fun, but doesn't particularly evolve past what you start with. Probably why it's considered the easy mode of the game. Modern Sonic is where all the best stuff is though. Levels are varied and the speed is ever more intense. You'll find a lot of the games better moments in the Modern Sonic portions. (Though Classic is still tons of fun as well.)

reviewText: Sonic Generations is the product of SEGA taking their most successful franchise and marinating it in a vat of liquid nostalgia. The result is a bittersweet trip through time--if you were there to appreciate it in the first places. While is doesn't quite live up to the legends of Sonic Adventure 2 and older, it's one of the company's better games in recent years. If you've never played Sonic games before, you might get some amusement out of its beautifully designed levels. If you're a diehard Sonic fan who has played every game since its conception, Sonic Generations is well worth the money to see some old favorites hit the HD screen.

reviewText: Sonic Generations is a fun game with both relaxing and very hard levels! The Good about this game is that there are so many levels to play in the game, so whenever you feel like playing a level, you got A LOT too choose from! There are also many characters from Sonic to Silver to Knuckles! Of course there are also many more such as Tails, Amy, Blaze, and Shadow, + More!\nEven though u got some characters that are not playable such as Omacho, you still can download mods to play some characters that never made it to the game as well as characters that aren't even in the Sonic Franchise! The Bad about this game is that there is a major amount of difficulties in the levels and they start to put you in RAGE MODE! Also, Sonic's character glitches a lot  when he's speed boosting and it could take a long time too get use to the controls! In all, I think this is a great way to celebrate the 20th year of Sonic and this game would get a rating of 8 out of 10 stars in my opinion!-NickTendo69

reviewText:
One of the best games of this generation.

Sega had a lot of difficulty creating a good 3d sonic game, sonic 3d was awful, sonic adventure was playable, but it wasnt untill sonic colours that they really managed to nail down sonic in a 3d enviorment.
However sonic generations will make you forget all about Sega's difficulties in getting sonic into 3D, because the game is one of the best games of this generation, it successfully takes the 3d sonic levels and makes them amazing, while also remembering just how good the 2d levels were and making sure that those were excellent as well, sonic generations is excellent and I look forward to sonics next game.

reviewText:
Sonic Generations is the best Sonic the Hedgehog game in the franchise, hands down.

Not only does it correct the wrongs that past Sonic games have done, it brings back all the good from both a 90's Sonic and Modern Sonic perspective. The gameplay is very smooth and the visuals are the best I've ever seen in any game ever!

Obviously, if you are a Sonic fan, you already have this, but if you don't, FOR SHAME!

I would not recommend this game to non-fans of the franchise, this game is purely meant for fan-service on an amazing scale to devoted followers like myself.

Overall this game gets my A/5, go buy this game, SEGA continues to redeem themselves.

reviewText: Sonic Genertaions is a game where Sega actually put in some effort. Voice acting is well done, Graphics are beautiful for the time, story is decent. It really shows what's possible with 3D Sonic games. The modern stages are wonderful and feel all around excellent to play, and are built well around how modern Sonic controls. Classic Sonic stages are...well classic! They give a good vibe and a bit of nostalgia to those, like myself, who've played the original Sonic games, Even the levels that were exclusive to modern Sonic felt right. This game however, is really short. Like, beat it in under 3 hours kinda short. I've beaten this on xbox, ps3 and PC and never felt happy with the length. Luckily, PC has mods. Some are still WIP, but level mods, character mods, and some goofy mods keep this game alive and well. Seriously, grab this game. It's a wonderful experience and shows Sonic at his best!

reviewText:
SONIC IS BACK !!!!!

Sonic Generations is the best sonic game to date. The game blends 2d with 3d gameplay and the result is a blast. The game is fast, challenging, beautiful and it’s the sonic that we remember from the Sega genesis “mega drive” era.
The story is also very good and it creates nostalgia. The music score it’s also awesome and it has some old school music from the old games.  Also there are lots of unlockables and secrets here. Each level also offers alternative routs and you can explore and find various secrets. Seriously if you are a sonic fun you will need to buy this.

Pros: Awesome levels, Nice Presentation, Looks great in motion, excellent level design, 2d and 3d blends perfectly, the 3d levels are fast as hell, voice acting is good, mods are available and you can play levels created by the community, high replayability

Cons: some minor bugs and some slow downs, some boss fights are boring.

FINAL SCORE: 08/10

I RECOMMEND TO PLAY WITH A GAMEPAD

reviewText: Although recent Sonic games have been notorious for being mediocre or flat out terrible, this one is actually quite good. You get a good mix of Sonic the Hedgehog's best levels from past games, playing in the perspective of both 2D Genesis Sonic, and 3D Dreamcast and Modern Sonic. Although the game is very short, there is still a lot of replay value. There are multiple mini games for each level, collectables, and of course, replaying levels to beat your best time and score. Another great aspect of this game is the mod community. Suprisingly enough, this game has built a fairly decent mod community. Mods for this game have been anywhere from character re-skins, to individual level designs, to Sonic levels that didn't make it into the game. All-in-all, this is a great game, and is worth a purchase.

reviewText:
Like Skyrim with fast
11/10 would fast again

Right now to the real review:
Sonic Generations came out back in 2011, so I am a little late to the party. But I might as well convince you to buy the game anyway.
Sonic Genrations takes Sonic and Co. on an adventure through Sonic's past. Classic stages such as Sonic 1's Green Hill Zone and Sonic Adventure 2's City Escape re-imagined for both modern Sonic, and classic Sonic. Modern Soinc plays the same as he does in the Unleashed Daytime Stages, and in Sonic Colours, sans wisps. (There is actually a mod called the Unleashed Project that brings stages from Unleashed onto PC). Classic Sonic plays like he does in Sonic 2, 3, and Sonic & Knuckles.
Both Sonics control very well. Controls can be a little sensitive at times but it's not a major problem.
The story is good, not great. But Sonic isnt as story-centrc as other games, so it's no big deal. A monster called the Time eater rips apart space and tme and Sonic saves the day with his past self.
The game has a surprisingly large modding community. There's  stage mods (The Unleashed Project, the STH2006 Project), and mods to replace sonic with Metal Sonic, Shadow, Silver, Blaze.... The list goes on and on.
There however a few problems I've had with the game, mainly being fps drops down as far as 10-15 at some times, however that may just be my hardware. (Intel HD 4000)
Overall I highly recommend this game to new and old Sonic fans alike. A blast of nostalgia for old fans and a Greatest Hits/Quickstart for new fans.
Sonic Generations gets a solid 8/10

reviewText: Probably my favorite, if not, my favorite Sonic game in the franchise. reviewText:
Sonic Generations is a true love letter to all Sonic fans. The levels are nostalgic and well designed, there's a ton of replayability with the missions and red rings, and, of course, the modding community for the Steam release. Not to mention the fantastic ear-melting soundtrack. I've owned this game for almost a year and I still go back to play it.

I will say, though, don't plan on expecting anything story-related as it's incredibly bare bones in terms of plot. The dialogue could have been better, as well... except for Eggman. He had the best lines in the game. I also think the graphics could have been touched up a little bit. It still looks great, though. Don't get me wrong.

Other than those complaints, I highly recommended this game to all Sonic fans old and new.

Score: 9/10
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game manages to capture the spirit of the early Sonic games and carries through with it from beginning to end. Classic Sonic and classic Robotnik are bawss, and all of the levels for classic Sonic play very nicely.

Modern Sonic, on the other hand, brought the entire cast and crew of his games - each one fresh out of whatever paintchip factory they had lunch at for the day. The last boss is a miserable experience because the colorful crew of critters ends up shouting advice into your ears the entire time.

TL;DR - Worth it for classic Sonic alone if you enjoyed the Sega Genesis games. Overall its a fun game, but a longtime fan will enjoy it more than someone new to the series given the references to the past in all of the levels.

reviewText: Sonic and I being the same age, I am literally a life long fan, in two senses of the phrase. Very rarely has a game met my expectations as well as this game has. The gameplay is basically right out of Sonic Colors and the day time levels of Unleashed, so basically, the best 3D gameplay the franchise has had, with the sidescrolling gameplay being excellent as well. Wrap that up with two versions of one fan favorite level from nine Sonic games, as well as two new versions of each stages song, and I'm a happy camper. The levels retain all the energy and life they started with, with their own new additional twists, and the remixed songs are great. Even better is that cool little surprises where things outside of the original stages being redone will be referenced, such as the Sonic Adventure 1 hotel making an appearance in that game's given stage. This is a must buy for Sonic fans, and I'd even suggest it for people that are just curious about the franchise.

reviewText:
Like Skyrim with fast
11/10 would fast again

Right now to the real review:
Sonic Generations came out back in 2011, so I am a little late to the party. But I might as well convince you to buy the game anyway.
Sonic Genrations takes Sonic and Co. on an adventure through Sonic's past. Classic stages such as Sonic 1's Green Hill Zone and Sonic Adventure 2's City Escape re-imagined for both modern Sonic, and classic Sonic. Modern Soinc plays the same as he does in the Unleashed Daytime Stages, and in Sonic Colours, sans wisps. (There is actually a mod called the Unleashed Project that brings stages from Unleashed onto PC). Classic Sonic plays like he does in Sonic 2, 3, and Sonic & Knuckles.
Both Sonics control very well. Controls can be a little sensitive at times but it's not a major problem.
The story is good, not great. But Sonic isnt as story-centrc as other games, so it's no big deal. A monster called the Time eater rips apart space and tme and Sonic saves the day with his past self.
The game has a surprisingly large modding community. There's  stage mods (The Unleashed Project, the STH2006 Project), and mods to replace sonic with Metal Sonic, Shadow, Silver, Blaze.... The list goes on and on.
There however a few problems I've had with the game, mainly being fps drops down as far as 10-15 at some times, however that may just be my hardware. (Intel HD 4000)
Overall I highly recommend this game to new and old Sonic fans alike. A blast of nostalgia for old fans and a Greatest Hits/Quickstart for new fans.
Sonic Generations gets a solid 8/10

reviewText:
Now for me the game was a must have, being a big Sonic fan and all. That last statement will probably mean I am extremely biased but man, this game is incredibly good.
Firstly the levels when you play in 2D or 3D (depending on the era) shows a really faithful remake that makes you fall in love with many levels all over again, and when you play the other act, taking your favourite 3D stages into 2D and vice versa it ends up putting a new feel to the levels which most of the time ends up being really fun to play. Admittedly I did have some issues with some later stages as sometimes the level design messed up the smooth flow the game had before, but overall the levels are incredibly good (And hey, they made Crisis city playable. Not necessarily good, but playable.)
The visuals are also really great, many levels in their remade form look lovingly crafted and really do make some stages (Like Green Hill Zone and City Escape) look brand new, hell I'd buy a Sonic 1 HD remake if they made it look like generations (Well I'd probably buy it anyway but still.).
Now I would recommend when you play this game that you use a controller, as a keyboard admittedly feels awkward when controlling Sonic in 3D. In 2D I didn't really have the same problems.
Overall this game is easily one of the best recent Sonic games and a must have for Sonic fans.
P.S. Wouldnt it be awesome if Sega added bonus DLC levels (not like the Casino Night pinball) where you get to play stages like Mystic Ruin and Ice Cap zone? Just imagine the levels remade in HD with redone music. You're welcome.

reviewText:
Wow, there's a whole lotta gravy in this game. If you are a fan of sonic games in general, you may want to pick this up.

First of all, let me mention that the gameplay itself is very swell.  The controls are pretty tight and while it doesn't reach the responsiveness of the Genesis games, it controls just dandy. Classic Sonic stages all take place in 2-D and they offer a great mix of speed and platforming just like the Genesis titles. Great work was done on the Classic stages.

The Modern Stages are also very godlike. They remind me very much of Sonic Unleashed and Sonic Colors and, for me at least, this was very sauce.  These stages have a great sense of speed and at times I even feel like a wild ape rampaging through the amazon rainforest.  Both gameplay styles are very fun and very sauce.

Perhaps the biggest selling point is the way this game caters to established fans of the series.  All of the stages in this game are remastered versions of stages from past Sonic games.  Stages like Chemical Plant Zone from Sonic 2, City Escape from Sonic Adventure 2, and Planet Wisp from Sonic Colors will be immediately recognizable to fans who have played them in past games but with the Classic/Modern gameplay split they feel new and as delicious as a barbequed almond roast.

The nostalgia in this game is huge and longtime Sonic fans will love it. But this is also where some people may not enjoy Sonic Generations.  For those of you who are not familiar with the series, a lot of Sonic Generations' appeal will be lost on you.  By itself the game is still very solid, but I imagine it is best to be played when you are more familiar with what the series has already done.

Speaking as a Sonic fan, however, I very much enjoyed this game. When I finished playing all the levels in the game I said Holy poopoo banana pants that was a good time". Any Sonic fan should definitely consider picking this game up.  If you haven't played Sonic games in the past this just might not be the best purchase
date: but i'd be lying if I said I didn't enjoy this game more than eating a medium-rare sauce steak.\n\nSonic Generations has been granted a rating of "Supreme Slam
recommended: Extreme Jam".  Thank you for reading."
hoursPlayed: July 2, 2013

reviewText:
Sonic generations... what can I say, I was a big fan of Sonic games on PC in my youth and tried coming back to try the new games in the series. Sadly they were incredibly frustrating, incredibly buggy or just plain painful to play, Sonic generations is the first attempt to fix this.

The game can be broken up into Act1 (Classic Sonic), Act2 (Modern Sonic), Boss battles (each boss fight has a particular Sonic mandatory) and finally challenges for each Sonic. Let's go over each of them:

Classic Sonic (Act1 of each stage): Classic Sonic is the sonic of our past with a bit of a modern twist on it. The levels are straight forward, simple to play and good fun. If you have played any Sonic game from the 90's then you will have no worries here. The only thing that will grab you is the occasional 3D feel it gives off.

Modern Sonic (Act2 of each stage): Modern Sonic is the character most associated with the bad Sonic games in a 3D world. Sonic generations gives modern Sonic high speed levels to play in at the start and it's a lot of fun seeing how fast you can clear a level. The later stages though are annoying and painful to say the least, it's at this point I started wished I could play the full game with just classic Sonic.

Boss fights: The bosses are a really strong point to this game, they are fun to play, the tactics aren't too hard and both Sonics feel really good to play as.

Challenges: Here is where the game really free falls to a large extent. At the beginning the challenges are really fun to play be it trying to out race a doppelganger or just use your skate/snow board to finish a level is great fun. Once those are done though it feels like the developers ran out of ideas and just made stuff up, the later challenges have you trying to collect rings in a fixed time (2 things I hate, collection duty with a time trial). Another one is hitting the level end sign to the end of the level or depending on side characters to help you, these are annoying and frustrating to say the least.

If you are a Sonic fan you should give it a go, for everyone else wait for 50% or more off.

reviewText:
Now for me the game was a must have, being a big Sonic fan and all. That last statement will probably mean I am extremely biased but man, this game is incredibly good.
Firstly the levels when you play in 2D or 3D (depending on the era) shows a really faithful remake that makes you fall in love with many levels all over again, and when you play the other act, taking your favourite 3D stages into 2D and vice versa it ends up putting a new feel to the levels which most of the time ends up being really fun to play. Admittedly I did have some issues with some later stages as sometimes the level design messed up the smooth flow the game had before, but overall the levels are incredibly good (And hey, they made Crisis city playable. Not necessarily good, but playable.)
The visuals are also really great, many levels in their remade form look lovingly crafted and really do make some stages (Like Green Hill Zone and City Escape) look brand new, hell I'd buy a Sonic 1 HD remake if they made it look like generations (Well I'd probably buy it anyway but still.).
Now I would recommend when you play this game that you use a controller, as a keyboard admittedly feels awkward when controlling Sonic in 3D. In 2D I didn't really have the same problems.
Overall this game is easily one of the best recent Sonic games and a must have for Sonic fans.
P.S. Wouldnt it be awesome if Sega added bonus DLC levels (not like the Casino Night pinball) where you get to play stages like Mystic Ruin and Ice Cap zone? Just imagine the levels remade in HD with redone music. You're welcome.

reviewText:
It’s been 20 years since Sonic rolled into the realm of games, and with him he’s brought us speed, clever level design and wonderfully imaginative set pieces. He has, however, also brought with him hideous 3d cameras, piles of buggy messes and a hedgehog who drives a jeep and carries a gun. Mixed legacy? You bet it is, and nowhere is the schizophrenic nature of the series better displayed than in the historically minded “Sonic Generations”. Is the blue blur back to his best, or is this simply another false start?

Sonic Generations begins optimistically, blasting through Green Hill Zone before being introduced to a charmingly “nod-nod wink-wink” opening cutscene that hints at a more light hearted Sonic adventure than other games have attempted. This reassuringly fun opening is cemented when, after finishing the first level with modern sonic, you think that you’re safe. Modern Sonic played fine, Classic Sonic was great, maybe we’re going to make the long haul here, maybe we can see the game through and not hit any major speed bumps. This goes on throughout the first third of the game, the level design is charming, the cutscenes are small and for the most part amusing, and the music is great. Then something happens, and a cold sweat sits in.

Challenges? There are challenges between the levels? The pulse quickens and blood drains from the face. Oh no. They surely didn’t mess this up, they were doing so well! Please don’t make me replay the same level to pad out gameplay please don’t... then the first genuine surprise happens. The challenges are not only really fun; they’re entirely different levels, for the most part! New power-ups are dished out in the form of Sonic’s friends and the level design shifts entirely. OK so these levels are much shorter, but they’re good, they’re fun, and best of all they take about 5 minutes at their most extravagant.
Then the first boss fight happens. It’s a mess; spotty controls, frustrating design and uninteresting music leads to the first true lull in the game. You can forgive it though, it isn’t too bad and it ended quickly once you figure out how to hurt the boss. But then you open up the Dreamcast era, and like Sonic does when he needs to go quicker, it goes downhill from there.

It’s incredible how Sonic Generations manages to pinpoint the exact moment Sonic jumped the shark but the history lesson is well taught. The level they chose from Sonic Adventure is a city level. The level they chose from Sonic Adventure 2 is a city level. The level they choose for Sonic 2006 is a city level. Suddenly it becomes very apparent that Sonic stopped existing in a sort of fantasy realm and started becoming an urbanite. All of the charm starts to drain, the level design gets, not exactly harder but more finicky, there’s more awkward jumps and bad precision platforming. Even worse are the glitches which suddenly pop up in Modern Sonic; blasting through walls, clipping on the edge of a platform and falling your death. Throw in more unexpected and unfair traps and it all gets a bit frustrating. Classic Sonic seems lost and bewildered in these later levels, outside his 3 games he has to wade through 6 modern titles and in almost every single one of them he is chased by something. I know Sonic being chased is a fun idea, but my god the poor ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ must be magnetic or something.

This is Sonic Generations biggest problem, while it’s great to celebrate Sonic’s past, it’s his present that is the true villain of the piece. What’s baffling is how the designers missed a trick in doing as little of the bad Sonic games as possible. They chose to include Sonic Heroes and Sonic 2006, and both of the “new levels” for those games are horrible. Why on earth recognise these infamously bad titles when you could have had a proper Sonic 3 level (the one in the PC version is Sky Sanctuary, a fine level but from Sonic and Knuckles) and brought in Sonic CD for a real nostalgia trip. Instead we get a bad beach level and a third (third!) city level. A terrible decision was made in development, but it could have been worse, we at least didn’t get a Shadow the Hedgehog level.

Towards the end the game feels like it might be getting a little stale, so it stops. With only 9 levels, and only 2 Sonics to play them with, Sonic Generations is short, but rightly so. The challenges become a little more cumbersome and tricky towards the end, and the final bosses are a teeth gnashing nightmare, but they are at least beatable. With 90 challenges to play and time trial modes to master some players will get tons out of the end game, but most users will be satisfied to put down the game after the final foe is foiled. I certainly am, and it’s an amicable separation, for £20 I felt I got what I paid for, and the game seems to breathe a sigh of relief that I’m asking no more of it.

As Sonic games go, Generations is a fun tribute. It remixes its ancestry but adds little to the series other than a recognition of when to bow out. Classic Sonic was fun to see again, but I doubt he’ll be back and it’s perhaps better that way, he’s had his day and now it’s his older, more jaded self that has to prove his worth. Modern Sonic is not redeemed by this title, and the later levels remind you that he still has his fair share of issues. But maybe he can move on, maybe someday we’ll get that 9/10 Sonic game that blows us away. This, though, is not that game, but it seems it was never meant to be. Short, silly and satisfying, Sonic Generations is a snacky game, not an epic event, and it’s nice to see something that knows its limitations. No melodrama, no over the top score, a fun run through the past of one of gaming’s most contentious icons and then off home with a smile on your face. It’s a better tribute than it ought to be.

*Game time has since been oosted by the incredible Sonic Unleashed Mod that adds the levels of Sonic Unleashed to the roster. Highly reccoomended.

reviewText:
At last, Sonic is back to PC. The Hedgehog Engine's port to Windows is clearly not optimized, and probably there are still lots of room for improvement on lower-end systems. Still, it's a marvel to look: from expressive and cartoony character animations to colorful scenery, it shines and glides through a beefy system.
Gameplay-wise, it's good for classic Sonic, and great for modern Sonic! The missions are a bit distractive and boring, but no serious flaw. The low number of bosses is also a let down.

Overall, it's a pretty enjoyable game, for both long-date Sonic fans and newbies alike, albeit a bit short.

reviewText:
I got this game as an early birthday present all the way back in March, and since then this has quickly become my most favourite Sonic game of all time. The controls are easy to get accostumed to, the game runs at a smooth 60FPS, the graphics and sounds are great and the music is some of the best in the entire series. It's also good to see Sonic's friends return after they'd been absent for a while, even if they aren't a major part of the game.
The strangest thing about Generations is that even though it is a super short game that could probably be beaten within a couple of hours, it is extremely replayable (even without mods).

If there are any complaints I have, well... the final boss is awful, some of the voice performances I'm not really keen on and the game does very occasionally freeze up to the point where the only way I can close it down is by restarting my PC. Besides that though? Totally recommend it.

reviewText:
By no means a perfect game. Not optimized to perfection for PC. Has a ton of bugs.

When you get past that though, its a really good game. One of the best Sonic games to be released in a while. Soundtrack is great, nostalgia is great, idea is great. A good happy birthday to the blue blur with an attitude. Takes a modern spin on classic Sonic and brings old school back to modern Sonic. If that makes any sense get this game. Get it while its on sale though, as said before a ton of bugs and its a rather short (yet sweet) game.
7.5/10 at the very least.

reviewText:
A mix of classic Sonic style and what a modern Sonic game should be. The modern sonic levels can be buggy sometimes, but notthing game breaking. The game gives you that sense of speed that every sonic game should.
Its always nice to have a game that is conscious of how rediculous it is, so it doesn't try being serious like some past entries. The perfect example is theres is a part where a giant semi truck is driving on the side of a building with rocket boosters and robotic saw arms chasing you.
My main complaint is that most of the boss fights are pretty lame, especially the final boss.
Overall though, this is a fantastic game and possibly the only good Sonic game we'll see in a long, long time.

reviewText:
After the release of the adventure series Sega have struggled to bring fans a game that was as good or better, with some entries, like Sonic unleashed actually being good (not counting any night stages) to the rushed and unfinished black sheep of the series released way back in 2006. That one game along with just passable entries released on down the line saw a lot of fans turn away from the franchise but I can tell you that this game is without a doubt the best Sonic game since Adventure 2.

Throughout the game you take on the role of classic sonic, who is played more like the original games in the style of 2D side scrolling but in more of a 2.5D type of style.

And of course you take control of modern Sonic who controls in more or less the same way as in Unleashed with some  side scrooling sections thrown in as well.

As a long time fan of the series it is really great to see that Sega can still make good Sonic games though the furure of the series is still up for debate with Nintendo now helping out for the next few games which probably means that we are going to see a rapid decline in fast paced gameplay and too much 'family friendly' content as shown by lost world and colours.

But overall if you are a fan of the series than you should definately think about buying  the game because it is filled with nostalgia, great gameplay and loads of replayability.

Though there are some bad points about the game, these points being that the game is only about 4 to 5 hours and all of the voice actors (with the exception of Eggman as his voice actor was the only one that didn't change after unleashed) are really bad even though some of them have done better in other performances.

Closing score: 97/100

reviewText:
Sonic Generations is a true love letter to all Sonic fans. The levels are nostalgic and well designed, there's a ton of replayability with the missions and red rings, and, of course, the modding community for the Steam release. Not to mention the fantastic ear-melting soundtrack. I've owned this game for almost a year and I still go back to play it.

I will say, though, don't plan on expecting anything story-related as it's incredibly bare bones in terms of plot. The dialogue could have been better, as well... except for Eggman. He had the best lines in the game. I also think the graphics could have been touched up a little bit. It still looks great, though. Don't get me wrong.

Other than those complaints, I highly recommended this game to all Sonic fans old and new.

Score: 9/10

reviewText:
This game manages to capture the spirit of the early Sonic games and carries through with it from beginning to end. Classic Sonic and classic Robotnik are bawss, and all of the levels for classic Sonic play very nicely.

Modern Sonic, on the other hand, brought the entire cast and crew of his games - each one fresh out of whatever paintchip factory they had lunch at for the day. The last boss is a miserable experience because the colorful crew of critters ends up shouting advice into your ears the entire time.

TL;DR - Worth it for classic Sonic alone if you enjoyed the Sega Genesis games. Overall its a fun game, but a longtime fan will enjoy it more than someone new to the series given the references to the past in all of the levels.

reviewText: Overall, Sonic Generations is an amazing game. If you ask me, it's the perfect way to celebrate Sonic the Hedgehog's 20th anniversary. Why? Not only do you get to play as Modern Sonic, but also Classic Sonic (he introduced me to videogames, believe it or not). So, needless to say, it can appeal to you whether you're a fan of the 2D, Genesis classics, or even the modern, 3D games. Every level has been taken from previous games in the series, all of which were voted to be in the game by the fans. One cool feature within the game is the ability to choose what music plays in the background of a level. You can unlock music through collecting red rings (returning from my favorite Sonic game, Sonic Colors) and completing challenges (a lot of which are a major pain in the neck to complete, let alone get an S-rank on). Oh, and if you were to ask me, I think people complain about the final boss fight WAY too much. It's not perfect, but it's not terrible, either (especially once you learn its attack-patterns and can collect rings efficiently). In conclusion, Sonic Generations doesn't quite have everything I expect to see from a Sonic game, but it is a masterpiece and it should be in every Sonic fan's collection.

reviewText:
Sonic Generations is the game that Sonic fans have wanted for years. SEGA's Sonic team has struggled to make Sonic work in the 3D space. But Generations handles it very well. Having both classic and modern Sonic help to facilitate two very different forms of gameplay. Classic Sonic's levels have a greater emphasis on platforming in 2-d esque stages. Modern Sonic has the bigger 3-D levels. A lot of these levels have sections that are on rails but these help lend a sense of speed. Modern Sonic also has some of his more recent tricks like his homing attack.

This contrast between the two gives the game variety. As you complete levels you progress through a simple but entertaining story. Like Mario; Sonic stories generally never get too deep or overly complex. The game avoids many of the errors Sonic games have had in the past; like shoehorning in new characters. In my time with the game I haven't met any new characters. Old familiar faces like Tails, Knuckles and Amy are present. Visually the game looks very nice indeed which is further helped by a mostly consistent framerate. I did have a few drops here and there however.

Having played Lost World I felt the level design was fantastic and the parkour system was an interesting new mechanic. If they could find a way to take the foundation of Lost World and marry that with the speed found in Generations I think it would make for quite a Sonic game. If you are a Sonic fan and have not played this game. This is definitely one you want to check out.

reviewText:
As a huge fan of the series I can say that this is the best modern sonic game.

If you like platformers - it's must have.
If you're not convinced about the series, it's the first game you should try.

+Two great gameplay styles (classic and modern).
+Dynamic arcade gameplay.
+Sense of speed.
+Good idea for a story.
+Very good replayability of the levels, many different ways to pass the stages, many additional missions, lots of secrets and unlockables, beating the time record of the stages to get higher ranks and compete in leaderboards.
+Epic boss battles.
+Great soundtrack.
+Nostalgia-filled levels.
+Very good graphics, plus PC version is way nicer and smoother than console versions.
+Great community-based mod support, lots of mods to download.
+AFAIK - very good use of stereoscopic 3D, also on PC.
+Unlockable Super Sonic for both regular classic and modern levels after beating the story.

-Minuses not noticed at all excepting very, very, occassional camera bugs at the start of the stage (restarting the level helps immediately; i noticed that after a long playtime after beating the story).
-Final boss battle could be done better, but overall it's not that bad.

reviewText:
Now for me the game was a must have, being a big Sonic fan and all. That last statement will probably mean I am extremely biased but man, this game is incredibly good.
Firstly the levels when you play in 2D or 3D (depending on the era) shows a really faithful remake that makes you fall in love with many levels all over again, and when you play the other act, taking your favourite 3D stages into 2D and vice versa it ends up putting a new feel to the levels which most of the time ends up being really fun to play. Admittedly I did have some issues with some later stages as sometimes the level design messed up the smooth flow the game had before, but overall the levels are incredibly good (And hey, they made Crisis city playable. Not necessarily good, but playable.)
The visuals are also really great, many levels in their remade form look lovingly crafted and really do make some stages (Like Green Hill Zone and City Escape) look brand new, hell I'd buy a Sonic 1 HD remake if they made it look like generations (Well I'd probably buy it anyway but still.).
Now I would recommend when you play this game that you use a controller, as a keyboard admittedly feels awkward when controlling Sonic in 3D. In 2D I didn't really have the same problems.
Overall this game is easily one of the best recent Sonic games and a must have for Sonic fans.
P.S. Wouldnt it be awesome if Sega added bonus DLC levels (not like the Casino Night pinball) where you get to play stages like Mystic Ruin and Ice Cap zone? Just imagine the levels remade in HD with redone music. You're welcome.

reviewText: Fab game. Why? Simple. Fixes everything that was wrong with Unleashed. Fast paced, great remakes of old stages from past games. 18 levels (thats 2 acts per zone and thats 9 zones) and a sh*t load of stuff to unlock and bonus challenges. What more can you ask for? I can tell you what you can ask for. Mods. This game is amazingly modable and I myself have played the Sonic Unleashed Day stages, levels from Sonic Adventure, Colours and even a few from Lost world. This game is perfect, replayable and best of all, (if you know how to mod) you can in some way create the perfect sonic game for you. Totally recommend this game. Im a massive Sonic geek and from me one of the best games this past decade of sonic games.

reviewText:
Pros
Old and new sonic stages remade for this game!
Amazing remixed sound track!
Graphically impressive for a sonic game
IT'S JUST SONIC! No nonsense with shadow, silver, etc
Powered up/new abilities with modern sonic makes game interesting
Classic sonic stages feel classic yet great, and some of my favorite stages
Bosses are fun, albeit a little easy outside of the end boss
Colors everywhere!

Cons
Story is a little simple, but it's a sonic game, so it makes sense
A little on the short side
This port isn't the best. Constant issues with configurations
Not many graphical options
The short missions that are required for you to do to get chaos emeralds are a little dull and kinda over extend the game

Overall, Sonic Generations is amazing. One of the best sonic games I've played. Me and my little nephew play this game all the time and we love it. I hope Sega goes back to this style of sonic games.
8.5 out of 10.

Get this game ASAP, because going fast will never feel any better.

reviewText:
I got this game as an early birthday present all the way back in March, and since then this has quickly become my most favourite Sonic game of all time. The controls are easy to get accostumed to, the game runs at a smooth 60FPS, the graphics and sounds are great and the music is some of the best in the entire series. It's also good to see Sonic's friends return after they'd been absent for a while, even if they aren't a major part of the game.
The strangest thing about Generations is that even though it is a super short game that could probably be beaten within a couple of hours, it is extremely replayable (even without mods).

If there are any complaints I have, well... the final boss is awful, some of the voice performances I'm not really keen on and the game does very occasionally freeze up to the point where the only way I can close it down is by restarting my PC. Besides that though? Totally recommend it.

reviewText:
MY DREAM SONIC GAME.
well, close to it lol.

The Sonic series has had a lot of falls like turning him into a were'hog',
throwing him on hoverboards, sticking him on a rail track, giving him a sword. It hasn't been too great..
Sonic 4 was alright. I recognize its flaws, but overall the games were pretty good. Sonic Colours was fun to play through, but not perfect. Sonic Unleashed's day stages were great fun to play through, but were very linear. The two racing games were pretty good too.

And finally, this game gets everything right. There's a great blend of sidescrolling and full 3d platforming. The stages are very well designed and its just what you'd want out of a modern Sonic game. Like the old classic games, there are so many alternate routes and paths. The linear level format of Unleashed is long gone and its done so much better. This really feels like a great modern take on the classic Sonic series and really what else should an anniversary remake be? The speed here is fast like Unleashed and the platforming isn't blocky like it was in Colours. There's a great blend of both
too - platforming and speed, that is.The choice of levels included is great and there's a classic and modern act for each. There's lots of gimmicky variations of the levels you can play as well, but that's mostly optional.

The visuals in this game are fantastic. The textures might not be the highest and it could use a little more AA, but it looks soooo good. One of my favourite artstyles I've ever seen in a game.

The music is really great too. It includes a bunch of remixes of tracks in the series as well as complete remakes of them. On top of that, you can unlock a bunch of different music and even change what plays in each level. Definitely a nice feature to have.

The story.. umm. yeah, the story isn't good. its just there. don't expect a good story in this one.

Also, the game is one of Sega's better ports and I'm glad to see them improving on that aspect. It runs quite well and I had very few issues with it. Though there was one problem with controllers. If you're using a controller other than a 360 pad, you might get a problem with Sonic automatically running to the side. Using a 360 controller or using x360ce (what I use) will fix it.

And of course there's mods. While there isn't tons of crazy mods out there, there are things like your normal character swaps, music changes, and even custom levels.
One really cool pack out there that adds a lot of value to this game is the Unleashed project. All (but one) of the day stages from Sonic Unleashed have been ported into this game and are fully playable on its engine.. and on PC. Awesome.

Overall this game is my favourite Sonic game ever. I may of spent tons of time with SA2 and Mega Collection's library of games many years back, but this game is just done so well.
I really loved playing through it and can't recommend it enough. Its not something that'll get you hundreds of hours unless you're mega hardcore with speed runs, but I really think its like the best Sonic game ever.
Buy it.

reviewText:
What can I say? It's one of the best 3D Sonic platformers ever made! And it made it to PC!
To be honest, when I bought this, I was expecting an easy game, with little to bo challenge, that I would be able to beat in a couple of hours (I'm looking at you Sonic Colors on the DS). Turns out I was wrong, and gladly wrong, because this game offers a great degree of challenge latter on. The levels are awesome and reminiscent of past Sonic levels, from the recognizable Green Hill Zone to the cloudy Sky Sanctuary Zone. The story is a hit or miss, way too childish and simple, I wish that Sonic games weren't targeted for a younger audience as they are now.
Overall a great experience, and one of the best platformers on Steam. You don't need to be a Sonic fan to apreciate the game, but it sure helps!

Edit: After playing the game a bit more to achieve 100% completion, I must add that while the controls are fine, I found myself struggling to make certain jumps (god, the frustration) and also found some glitches related to the camera - the camera stays on the side, when it should be centered, makes it hard to platform, when drifting the camera decides to wander off, that sort of thing. Also, the game often crashed when trying to play ranked time attack online, not to mention that the leaderboards are completely hacked, with people having completion times of 00m00s!
Other than that, I still recomend this game.

reviewText:
By no means a perfect game. Not optimized to perfection for PC. Has a ton of bugs.

When you get past that though, its a really good game. One of the best Sonic games to be released in a while. Soundtrack is great, nostalgia is great, idea is great. A good happy birthday to the blue blur with an attitude. Takes a modern spin on classic Sonic and brings old school back to modern Sonic. If that makes any sense get this game. Get it while its on sale though, as said before a ton of bugs and its a rather short (yet sweet) game.
7.5/10 at the very least.

reviewText:
A mix of classic Sonic style and what a modern Sonic game should be. The modern sonic levels can be buggy sometimes, but notthing game breaking. The game gives you that sense of speed that every sonic game should.
Its always nice to have a game that is conscious of how rediculous it is, so it doesn't try being serious like some past entries. The perfect example is theres is a part where a giant semi truck is driving on the side of a building with rocket boosters and robotic saw arms chasing you.
My main complaint is that most of the boss fights are pretty lame, especially the final boss.
Overall though, this is a fantastic game and possibly the only good Sonic game we'll see in a long, long time.
