reviewText:
Sonic Generations is a huge tribute to the most popular Sonic game, you can have both the old school sonic and the modern sonic styles of game and the most remembered scenarios and songs from previous Sonic games also has a lot of great artwork, unfortunately has several bugs and i don't recommend you to complete all the achievements.. is too hard with those bugs

Gameplay 8/10
I loved the gameplay, you will have 9 scenarios over 2 acts, these scenarios are map inspired and almost the same from Sonic 1, 2, 3, Sonic & Knuckles, Sonic Adventure 1 & 2, Sonic The Hedgehog, Sonic Unleashed and Sonic Colors. Can seem that are not many maps, but you can play also over 90 challenges.

Classic Sonic mode: is the classic platform mode, when you clear the challenges you can use the Electric, Fire, Bubble and Sonic 1 shields.
Modern Sonic mode: is a third person mode, in which sonic can lock and hit targets and use Turbo, the third person perspective switches with a platform in several part of each map.

The only thing i hate was the final boss fight, i didn't get anthing that was going on.. to much effects weird angles.. and also for me there was several maps in modern sonic that were tricky and confusing but if you play Sonic Adventure previously, this probably won't be an issue.

The difficulty of the game is up to you, you can try to get S in all the stages, and make all the challenges, or simply pass the story, but all the boss fights are very easy.. like in every Sonic games the boss has simple patterns.

I took me 29 hours to unlock all the Achievements, because of a bug took me some hours to figure it out.
Just plaing the story with cinematics can be done in 5, you are forced to play some challenges to unlock the new stages.

Graphics 9/10
The graphics are pretty descent the only problem is playing using Steam Streaming, i tried but for some reason the image capture of Steam was too slow and couldn't play it that way. And the 2d to 3d charater transformation were great.

Sound & Music 9/10
The music and sounds are from the previous Sonic games but with a loot of more quality, brings my childhood back each time i hear the Sonic spins, hits fire shield sounds etc. I think the sound work is awesome.

Bugs & stability 5/10
Several times i found bugs, like the Ranked Attack maps crashes every time... i could find how to skip" the bug but also has a lot of work and very frustrating...
Some scenarios had a few parts with bad collision but almost never caused me getting kill.

Total 7/10
I totally recommend you this game if you love classics Sega Genesis Sonic i guarantee that you will enjoy it and bring your childhood back a couple of hours. I hope this review were useful to you and tanks for reading.

Regards!"

reviewText: For a game that celebrates the anniversary of a previously good franchise, this game sure does reek of all the reasons I hate Sonic nowadays. I was disappointed at how mind numbingly good this game could've been. But the lack of structural cohesiveness in the boss fights and modern Sonic controlling worse than a drunk 16 year old midget made this game a mildly tedious experience at best and a frustrating mess at worst.\n\n10/10.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
If you grew up playing Sonic games, then this game is a must. It's essentially a throwback to Sonic games from each major Sega era: Genesis, Dreamcast, Modern. Seeing old levels reimagined in 3D, or even in 2D with updated visuals, is a blast.

The gameplay is fluid and fast. The graphics are absolutely stunning (even on my 6 year-old Alienware M17 Laptop). The music is everything you'd hope it would be.

This is definitely worth your time. It's good to play a good sonic game after such a long period of mediocrity.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Incredibly fun, fast paced, and nostalgic game!

Music - The music is such a huge part of the game for me. You can unlock new songs and listen to any song you've ever unlocked while play through any stage or mission. That and a few remixes in this game are just amazing. Favorite remixes are probably the Shadow's battle theme remixed, Super Sonic Racing (Generations mix), and Speed Highway (Modern remix.) But every stage has two remixes it to it (sans boss battles and side missions) that bring back lots of good and bad memories (that damn tornado, ughhhhhh.)

Levels - The stages are great and some have achievements are nice little cameo appearances of one time characters appearing here and there in the background somewhere (Fang, Bean, and Polar for example appear on some posters in City Escape.) The levels have entirely nice design although I feel a few of them could have been much better done to either be harder or less of a pain to complete.

Story - Same old, same old, Dr. Robotnik(s) up to their old shenanigans as per usual. Nice trip down memory lane regardless.

Bonus - The hidden trophy room, good luck figuring out ALL the codes for the trophies (most likely will use a guide like I did since there's no real indication the room exist or how to find and get the codes.) The content room has the FMVs, concept art, character info, and music for enjoyment.

Game play - Modern and Classic Sonic vary in play style (although you can eventually unlock Homing Attack for Classic Sonic which takes forever to do.) Classic Sonic is side scrolling and using older game style controls, Modern Sonic uses newer playing styles and can't spin dash sadly but can go into Boost Mode and pick up really nice speed.

Overall, I would recommend this game, whether it be part of the bundle, stand alone, or on discount. :)

reviewText: This game makes me happy for Sonic Team.  After years of trying to capture what made the Genesis games good, to varying degrees of success, they've finally nailed it - and fixed most of 3D Sonic's flaws for good measure.  Level design has plenty of alternate routes and chances for exploration without slowing you down, and stylistically I'm too busy fanboying over the nostalgia to really be an impartial judge (but god *damn* does Chemical Plant Zone look like the daydreams I had when I was a little kid).

reviewText:
Sonic has had a much bumpier career than Mario with his missing appearance on the Saturn, his first adventure into 3D having not aged too well, his first anniversary game being one of the worst games of all time (Sonic '06) and the attempts to fix the franchise afterword resorting to ripping off other non-related games (like God of War). That said, things have been looking good for Sonic ever since Colors came out and Generations does to some extent build on that momentum and even fix many of the problems with the previous 3D Sonic games. Of course much like Sonic's career, Generations has numerous flaws that keep it from reaching the peak of platforming bliss that old Jumpman set.

Let's start off with the good: Generations looks and sounds great with crisp graphics, beautiful environments and some of the series best tunes in one package. Both the 2D and 3D levels are mostly fun (with a few disappointing exceptions) and in some cases even fix what weren't really fun levels before (such as '06's Crisis City). The controls are spot on and it seems they have almost perfected 3D Sonic's move set (almost, one of the missions proves that the Homing Attack is still a bit tricky) while 2D Sonic feels just like he did in the old games, which is funny given how odd Sonic 4 felt. The Story is nothing special, but it's not contrived and stupid like in Adventure 2 and '06, plus there are some funny lines here and there. Also the new not-4KIDS cast is great (even though Robotnik is still played by the same actor) and they fit the roles well without any weird ear bleeding voices making you reach for the mute button.

As I said though, the game does have flaws that keep it from being a proper classic. For one thing, the game just feels padded. There are 9 levels (3 from each era: the Genesis Era, the Adventure Era and the Modern Era) with 2 acts each, 4 boss fights and 3 rival bosses. Given the general brevity of a standard Sonic level, this makes the game sound a bit short, even compared to other Sonic games. This is where the missions come in. In order to gain access to a boss of a given era, you have to get a key from each of the 3 levels. You get a key by completing missions (there are 5 for each level for both old and new Sonic), which you really only have to beat 1 of in each level. This is thing though; if you are only expected to do 1 per level, then why not just add a 3rd act? Reusing the existing level's assets for random missions just feels like they were tacked on at last minute or added to save money and really they just feel like filler. Franky, adding a 3rd act and just having the missions be completely optional would have been the better option.

The other issue is that the missions them selves are mostly not fun. In fact a few are what I'd call anti-fun" (the Vector music note one is one of the worst things I've ever played in my life). I can think of several that were no fun at all
date: but can't think of one that was fun off the top of my head. I'm sure there were a few
recommended: but they just don't leave an impression on you. The other issue is that while they fixed many levels that weren't fun in old games
hoursPlayed: they actually ruined one that was fun
voteText: that being Planet Wisp. I personally love Sonic Color
helpfulPercent: so I was excited to see what this level was like
votesHelpful: but I was saddened to see that they didn't use any actual level from the game. I can understand for the 2D act (which was even less fun)
votesTotal: but not the 3D one. How could they keep the '06 level mostly intact and then just ignore all the levels in Colors? What a waste.\n\nThose problems aside

Playing this game was pretty fun.
Controls well. Brings back classic stages. Adds a story.
And playing some of the stages from the older games is fun especially the opposite era (Like Modern sonic in Genesis titles and Classic sonic in everything else)

Still @#$% Planet Wisp though... and the machspeed segments in all the levels ESPECIALLY the stage (of which I can't remember as of now ) from Sonic 06 UGH! Oh GAWD WHY!

The challenges for both classic and modern sonic stages adds more" to the game I guess. Just throwing some difficulties and stuff in there in which you would normally not do.

However I wish each stage had its own boss like in the classic games and then a final boss although that might be overkill I guess? Probably an idea they had but didn't implement because it'd be too much.

reviewText: Personally, I think this is the best Sonic game ever. It doesn't have the most detailed storyline, but that's okay. The music and levels are great on thier own, and I love replaying them. reviewText:
While it has faults, with some of the later stages slowing things down to a crawl, the majority of this game is just so much damned fun.  It really captures the essence of Sonic.  Not only are the 2d stages great, but the 3d ones work very well for the most part.  The only times that the 3d stages fall apart are when the game no longer has you pinned to a 2d plane.

The story is hokey but, you know what, that's actually kind of what I want out of a Sonic game.

It's hard to say much else about Generations because when the stages aren't entirely cut and pasted from other games, they're very VERY inspired from stages in previous iterations.  Unfortunately you can also gauge how entertaining they'll be based on where they came from (Hint: the sonic colors stages are awful, as are the Sonic Heroes stages).

I may have said some negative things but I had an amazing time with this game and I'm very glad it existed.  Sega could stop making Sonic games right here and I would be happy because we've finally gotten a good one.  If you've ever enjoyed a Sonic game, I really think this should be in your library.

reviewText:
Sonic Generations is a huge tribute to the most popular Sonic game, you can have both the old school sonic and the modern sonic styles of game and the most remembered scenarios and songs from previous Sonic games also has a lot of great artwork, unfortunately has several bugs and i don't recommend you to complete all the achievements.. is too hard with those bugs

Gameplay 8/10
I loved the gameplay, you will have 9 scenarios over 2 acts, these scenarios are map inspired and almost the same from Sonic 1, 2, 3, Sonic & Knuckles, Sonic Adventure 1 & 2, Sonic The Hedgehog, Sonic Unleashed and Sonic Colors. Can seem that are not many maps, but you can play also over 90 challenges.

Classic Sonic mode: is the classic platform mode, when you clear the challenges you can use the Electric, Fire, Bubble and Sonic 1 shields.
Modern Sonic mode: is a third person mode, in which sonic can lock and hit targets and use Turbo, the third person perspective switches with a platform in several part of each map.

The only thing i hate was the final boss fight, i didn't get anthing that was going on.. to much effects weird angles.. and also for me there was several maps in modern sonic that were tricky and confusing but if you play Sonic Adventure previously, this probably won't be an issue.

The difficulty of the game is up to you, you can try to get S in all the stages, and make all the challenges, or simply pass the story, but all the boss fights are very easy.. like in every Sonic games the boss has simple patterns.

I took me 29 hours to unlock all the Achievements, because of a bug took me some hours to figure it out.
Just plaing the story with cinematics can be done in 5, you are forced to play some challenges to unlock the new stages.

Graphics 9/10
The graphics are pretty descent the only problem is playing using Steam Streaming, i tried but for some reason the image capture of Steam was too slow and couldn't play it that way. And the 2d to 3d charater transformation were great.

Sound & Music 9/10
The music and sounds are from the previous Sonic games but with a loot of more quality, brings my childhood back each time i hear the Sonic spins, hits fire shield sounds etc. I think the sound work is awesome.

Bugs & stability 5/10
Several times i found bugs, like the Ranked Attack maps crashes every time... i could find how to skip" the bug but also has a lot of work and very frustrating...
Some scenarios had a few parts with bad collision but almost never caused me getting kill.

Total 7/10
I totally recommend you this game if you love classics Sega Genesis Sonic i guarantee that you will enjoy it and bring your childhood back a couple of hours. I hope this review were useful to you and tanks for reading.

Regards!"

reviewText:
I can't really say much about this game, sure, it tries to leech your nostalgia, but it's good, so it dosen't matter. The only bad things i can say about it are these:
1. The game has no default bindings, and you have to bind your keys based off of an XBox 360 controller, so if you've never used that controller and you don't know what the buttons mean, you're screwed. Also, to change your key bindings, you have to exit the game and launch a seperate program to change it.
2. Remember those stupid platformers like Bubsy? Where the camera is zoomed in so much you can barely see what's ahead of  you? this game does that, at least only in the classic style levels.
3. Modern sonic is confusing, it goes from on rail dodging to 3D platforming to 2D platforming all in the same level, and it also uses the sholder buttons for the XB360 controller, so if you bound those to a button out of basic reach, you're screwed.
Other than that, the game is great on it's own merit. And THANK GOD you can turn omochau off,  He dosen't bother me at all, but i guess that's because i've never played sonic adventure.
What else? uhhh, that's it. It just re-uses all of the classic sonic stages from your childhood, or later, to try and leech your nostalgia, and it's good.
8/10.

reviewText: In my opinion this is the best Sonic game made. I feel the gameplay may have been made a little too easy yes, but this makes it fun for players to get good times on stages. The only cons about this game are that it's a bit short, you can only have one save file and the easiness. But I still I don't think this game deserves any less than 7/10. This game appeals to both classic Sonic game (Sonic 1-Sonic 3 and Knuckles) and more modern-ish Sonic game lovers (Sonic Adventure-Sonic Colors). The game has amazing graphics, which is great for sonic lovers that always wanted to see they're favourite stages in HD, The physics are good, the gameplay is fun, and it is pretty much flawless. I personally would rate it 9.5/10 being an almost perfect game in my eyes.

reviewText:
well I must say that the game isnt running particularly fast on my laptop (~25fps, not really a problem since i even play racing game with this fps count fine), but is isnt that easy to control, especially since sonic literally doesnt seem to know when to stop and sometimes the fine steering while jumping isnt really precise so it's a bit hard to hit a small target like a jumping platform.
But almost every game has positive aspects and let's rather talk about those.
for Starters I think it's great to have the ability to choose the voice language to your liking and they even had the Japanese voices in it, a fact which I truly loved (and instantly enabled) since at least in my experience ENglish or German voices are usually a lot inferior to Japanese ones both in Anime and games that I watched/played.
Even though it isnt perfect, in the end it isnt a bad game and the idea of combining a pure side scrolling Jump 'n Run with a 3D Jump 'n Run is great. in the end I like it. maybe the controls are better on my PC, I'll try to update this when I get a chance to play on my PC.

reviewText: If a time machine will ever be created, I'd use it for two things. The first one is to see attend the first public screening of the Empire Strikes Back. The second thing is to buy the original three Sonic games for the Megadrive and play the hell out of them again. Thankfully, Sonic Generations makes the neccesity for the latter obsolete as it is exactly that. Sonic Generations takes me back to my gaming genesis (pun intended). The music, the level design, the atmosphere, everything breathes old-school super Sonic. And guess what, the new sections are also really good. I paid full price for this gem when it came out and money well spent. So any chance to get it cheap is a godsend. Generations gives you control of 2 different sonics. Not just in appearence, but also in gameplay. Speed is core in this game and it leaves nearly all Sonic's recent outings in the dust. Generations is a must-buy for sonic fans and a great purchase for those looking for great fun, whether classic or modern.

reviewText:
Sonic Generations is a celebration of Sonic 20th year of video gaming history, this title has no big complex plot just a normal Sonic game this time around, unlike Sonic's 15th celebration with broken game play and awful story, this game is good and I can say they did one hell of a good job with this one. The story, I can't say that it will be the most understandable but at least it's simple and only has one story this time unlike 2006's Sonic the Hedgehog.

The Music:
When it's good damn it's good; only a few tracks are off in this title, notably Sonic 2's chemical plant act2 and Sonic Adventures City Escape act2.

Sonic Generations is a buggy mess of a game, but at least it can be fun, even if there are a lot of flaws that I think could have been worked out with a little more testing and feedback from longterm fans of the sonic the hedgehog franchise.

I could only think they Sonic Rushed it out the doors of there offices before even testing it for last minute bug fixes, the 3d engine camera is very broken and can even be broken from normal game play, this seems to be the case for all version of the game so if you think it’s just the PC version.


PC port specific errors:

Online mode crashes:
Even with a normal everyday Internet connection, this makes very little sense, the only thing it should be doing it downloading the scores and uploading the fastest time you have set in online time attack. If your Internet is slow even by a little bit or even if it is fast, it crashes and have you to restart the game to try again and hope to Jesus the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ will not crash again.

Game Controller Support is broken:
If you have a xbox360 controller it works fine, if you don’t well you will have to download and install a modded pad input emulator to get the damn thing to work.

No window mode:
This is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ move that game programmers have made before, nothing to bad but if you wanted to do this well damn.

Video config glitch:
If you update your video card drivers and you then you try and play the game, it will give you an error and say for you to run the config, then after doing so nothing changes, it will keep giving you an error until you go into the game folder and delete a config file before you can play the game again.

reviewText:
// Sonic Generatio is a 2D & 3D Adventure Game: //
// Schuitje82 - Extended Review //

About:
======
Finally after years of bad games Sonic Generations is a great game.
Sonic Generations is a look at the past of the Sonic games.
Many levels come back from Sonic 1, 2, 3 as the adventure series.
What I think it's very special that you can play all stages in 2d as 3d perspective.
Overall a very unique concept that makes this game special in his own way.

Story:
=====
Story mode is about you are facing Dr. Eggman & Time Lord (what his name is) together with Old & Next Gen Sonic.
You run with both character though stages to rescue your buddies who are traped in the stages / time line.
When you complete 2d and the 3d part the stage will unlock and you have saved your friend.

Gore Gameplay:
============
The game is not only about the story mode and running.
Beside the main story mode the games gives you a ♥♥♥♥ load of extra challanges to play.
Like Time Trail, Defeating Bosses like Metal Sonic, Collecting Items with knuckles.
There is so many things to do in this game this will keep you playing for hours and hours.
And gives the game a good variation.
There is a ingame pinball table... only this is DLC content :(

Graphic & Controls:
===============
They did a great job with the graphic part of this game.
If you PC can handle the game this game looks SuperB on Max settings.
The game supports the The Xbox 360 joypad.
Did not tested it with other controllers.
Game plays very well and gives you the old feeling like the Sega era back in the '90.

Overall:
=======
Game looks great, great music and really has the feel of my childhood sonic game.

Score: 9

http://store.steampowered.com/app/71340

reviewText:
Sonic Generations is probably the best Sonic Game I've played since Sonic Rush or Adventure 2. (Not counting All Stars Racing Transformed. )

If you enjoyed the original 2D sonic games, then you'll find something here.
If you enjoyed the 3D games, you'll find something here.

It's a great mix of the old and new. Every level is nostalgic, yet they still have hints of new things and shortcuts, etc. The boss battles are entertaining, aside from the lackluster final boss.

There's alot of extra content such as ghost races and other trials to compete in, and you can unlock a fair amount of stuff, including Sonic 1 for the Genesis.

My only real complaint is that the Sonic Colors stage sucks no matter what Sonic you play as (Classic or Modern) and Crisis City from Sonic 06 is pretty much as bad as it was in 06.

I'd definitely pick this up if  you enjoyed any previous Sonic games.

I'd give this a  FAST/10.

reviewText: To be quite honest, this is the best Sonic game I've played in a very long time. While it isn't too great on its story aspects, it delivers amazingly on what Sonic fans care the most about - Gameplay. The Classic Sonic gameplay found in the game appeals to even those who weren't very fond of the classic games, since it's easier to get the gist of and is required for less than half of the game. Modern Sonic's gameplay in this game is basically what it was in Unleashed, except with 90% of the issues fixed. And, with no night time stages to hold you back, the only disappointing thing about Modern Sonic is the lack of levels, since you only get nine levels with four boss fights, and some(lame) modified layouts of those levels. This is where the modding community comes in, though. Thanks to modding, this game's faults can all be fixed with additional content, and even content from the previous games. As someone who enjoys Sonic, you really would owe it to yourself to buy this game, especially during a sale.

reviewText:
Few characters can say they've had as many ups and downs as Sonic the Hedgehog. For better or for worse, the Sonic franchise has carved out a long timeline with a lot of changes over the years. Generations is a look at both the old and the new.

Sonic Generations is split into Classic and Modern levels, Classic as the 2D Genesis-era sidescroller era and Modern as the 2D/3D platforming speedways. Classic levels play pretty much how one would expect. The physics and momentum aren't quite as tight as the old Genesis games, but they're quite good, and it's a blessing to have the Spindash keyed to one button.

Modern levels are a bit more mixed. On one hand, it's clear that this is the evolution of what we saw in Sonic Unleashed and Sonic Colors: a crazy blitz through lush environments, relying on reflexes and intuition to keep the flow from action to action. While it's an absolute joy to punch through a successful speedrun, it's easy to break out of the flow, and find yourself wrestling awkwardly to get yourself back to speed. Seems that you're either super fast or awkwardly trying to speed back up. Old 3D Sonic problems rear their head, sometimes awkward turning and immediate stops and the like. Que sera.

Nostalgia runs rampant. Fans of the series will be really pleased with the details. Sonic Heroes era Badniks still do the little detection jump before they attack, the snowboard from City Escape returns, the stages use the classic camera angles for the stage openers. I found myself smiling at the little things. Props to the composers for a fantastic OST.

The game is a bit short. 9 levels with a Classic and modern version, some old favorite boss battles and padded challenges round the game out, but I can't help but want much more.

Generations is quite flawed, but the sheer spectacle of the speed and adrenaline can't be beat. It's fun.

reviewText:
Game: Sonic Generations
Genre: Adventure
Developer: Sonic Team/SEGA
System: Steam/PC
Total Score: 96/100
Value Score: 9.6/10

• Story: 9/10
o Sonic the Hedgehog was having a birthday party with all the friends he has made in over the past couple of years. However something off in the distance a dark ominous being appeared and sucked everyone up and leaving both Sonic and Tails confused at what happened in a unknown mysterious space void. There they find themselves in a familiar location and as they traveled around they managed to find younger form of themselves. Now both Sonics and Tails will be going on a new journey to save their friends and their own respected times and worlds.

• Characters: 10/10
o Almost every single Sonic series hero and villain appear in this game. There are some ones who do not make an appearance but all of the major characters from the past few generations do appear. You have characters like Sonic and Tails from both the past and present, Dr. Eggman of the past and present, Amy, Shadow the hedgehog, Rouge, Knuckles and the rest from Colors, Unleashed and etc. The enemies are also the same depending on the level of which game it reflects off from. Some of the notable bosses as well from the past games also make an appearance. Sonic Generations is pretty much like a reunion for the Sonic the Hedgehog franchise.

• GamePlay: 9/10
o Sonic Generations plays differently from the older Sonic games. For one thing levels and stages are divided into different areas from past Sonic games and you can access them through as Classic Sonic or Modern sonic in a world map like sidescroller style. Playing as either sonic will alter the gameplay and changes the whole design of a level/stage. Classic Sonic's gameplay style is more old school 2D view while Modern Sonic's is mostly 3D view like recent Sonic games. There are three levels with each area having a mini boss and a boss at the end of the three levels. Defeating each mini boss and boss earns you a chaos emerald which is used to fight the last boss at the end of the game. Each level consists stages from different eras of Sonic - in the PC version which is the same as the home console versions, the levels and stages are included as : Classic Era - Green Hill from Sonic the Hedgehog, Chemical Plant from Sonic the Hedgehog 2 and Sky Sanctuary from Sonic the Hedgehog 3 & Knuckles. The Dreamcast era includes Speed highway from Sonic Adventure 1, City Escape from Sonic Adventure 2 and Seaside hill from Sonic Heroes. The Modern era which is the last era has Crisis City from Sonic the Hedgehog 2006, Rooftop Run from Sonic Unleashed and Planet Wisp from Sonic Colors. The usual gameplay rules apply to both modern and classic sonic - collecting rings and racing your way towards the exit marker at the end of the stage after avoiding all sorts of enemies and obstacles. For Modern sonic you can super speed dash upon a limitation bar which can be increased by collecting rings while classic sonic mainly plays like the old Sonic games with little to no difference. The level designs for each type is completely different even though it may be in the same stage. You have the usual power ups such as invincibility, shields which range from the regular green shield, the electric shield which absorbs rings, the fire ring which can make Sonic shoot like a fireball and the water shield which Sonic can use to breathe underwater or to have a extra bounce. Upon completing stages you will get access to additional missions which base around the level of where these missions are located (which is above each level entrance). These missions also vary depending on which Sonic you play as and will have a different requirement or goal as well which can range from completing a level, fighting/competing with a rival, collecting certain number of rings or simply surviving amongst other things. Completing these missions will earn you a point towards the achievement of completing all the missions and allows you to unlock a artwork or a music track which can be used optionally on other stages. Red stars also make an appearance in which goes towards your achievement scoring and is counted towards the completion of the game. A new feature introduced to the Generations game is the ability to buy power ups or abilities which can be equipped upon purchase with a limitation on how many you can equip by the number of points it requires compared to how many you have in total. Abilities and power ups range from simple power ups depending on certain situations happening automatically, the inclusion of new speed abilities or the ability to protect yourself with some bonuses such as keeping a few rings even after taking a hit instead of losing all your rings. There's also a special room where you can go and check on character profiles, listen to the game's OST or to even look at some promotional artwork designed for the game. The online feature of the game introduces you to a competitive circuit where you are forced to do a level and are ranked by the time and score upon completion which then gets displayed in a leader boards for bragging rights.

• Graphics: 10/10
o Sonic Generations use a new style of visual design and fluidity for its cutscenes however the in gameplay seems to be similar to what you would expect see in a HD version of Sonic Colors and of Sonic the Hedgehog 4. The new cutscenes seem reminiscent of a typical western influenced platformer which isnt a bad thing. The visual designs for the characters look great especially on the older versions of characters. The environments re-done from past Sonic games look incredible with the new style and brings a whole new depth to whatever the player had imagined beforehand in the past games. There are some slow down and FPS drops but that is only because you would need a stronger CPU than what is recommended but by not that much and not very noticeable.

• Sound: 10/10
o Sonic Generations have managed to keep majority of the voice overs for their characters from all eras including the eras without voice overs are nicely done and you can tell the difference in the quality/type of voice. However even though Sonic doesnt talk might be a bad thing - what was worse is the fact that Shadow and Rouge's voice actors were changed but it isnt bad to the extent where they sound completely off. The sound effects which were made famous in the older sonic games and all of the other games make a complete return.

• Music: 10/10
o Sonic Generations consists of a mixture of old classic tracks, original tracks from modern games and remixes of all of the songs with a bit of new tracks exclusive to the game. The remixes are actually quite well made and some of them are even BETTER than the originals. Another nice thing that they added is the ability to change the music when you play in a stage. Simply upon clicking to start on a stage change the music to whatever you have unlocked via playing missions.

• Length: 9/10
o Sonic Generations although might seem a bit short but it takes a lot of time and dedication to get all the red stars, perfect score points upon completion and to get every single music/artwork unlocked. At the most you will complete at least 12-15 hours on a straight way playthrough with minimal missions completed. For a platformer that is a pretty decent amount since most platformers are usually done within 7-10 hours.

• Replay Value: 10/10
o Sonic Generations most powerful aspect is possibly its replay value aspect. With the ability to play in over 50 different stages over the choice of 7+ maps that seems to be a pretty hefty amount considering if you add the mini bosses and the bosses you fight along the way along with some of the things you need to collect such as Red stars which will eventually make you play through the levels multiple times.

reviewText: Sonic Generations. A title that is really good, and has a lot of replay value, but it really... understates its welcome? It has a (slightly) diverse range of remade levels from past games, and both Sonics control beautifully, but it's pretty damn short, and $50 is honestly just overpriced. But when I say replay value, I MEAN IT. It has lots of stuff to collect, including concept art for Sonic games from the past, and even MUSIC from Sonic games from the past! The levels always leave something new for every playthrough, first or not, and keep you playing over and over again. The remixes used for levels are downright AWESOME, and the bosses provide a fair challenge while not being too overly frustrating- very rarely do I ever rage-quit because of a boss. Overall, it makes its place well in the Sonic franchise, and it's an amazing 20th anniversary title. However, the story is so simplistic that it's almost bland, and it just screams missed opportunities. But it does have, yep, a modding community! You can download and play a diverse range of mods that can have new stages, characters, bosses... anything, really! Overall, it's a good game, but a bit overpriced. I recommend it to Sonic fans old and new. Heck, even if you're not a fan of Sonic, just give this game a go. You might end up loving it!

reviewText:
Uh
Not too sure what to write here so heres a recipe for Pancakes instead

Ingredients:
1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour
3 tablespoons sugar
1 tablespoon baking powder
1/4 teaspoon salt
1/8 teaspoon freshly ground nutmeg
2 large eggs, at room temperature
1 1/4 cups milk, at room temperature
1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract
3 tablespoons unsalted butter, plus more as needed

Now to make it
1. In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, baking powder, salt, and nutmeg.
2. In another bowl, beat the eggs and then whisk in the milk and vanilla.
3. Melt the butter in a large cast iron skillet or griddle over medium heat.
4. Whisk the butter into the milk mixture. Add the wet ingredients to the flour mixture, and whisk until a thick batter is just formed
5. Keeping the skillet at medium heat, ladle about 1/4 cup of the batter onto the skillet, to make a pancake. Make 1 or 2 more pancakes, taking care to keep them evenly spaced apart. Cook, until bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, and the undersides are golden brown, about 2 minutes. Flip with a spatula and cook about 1 minute more on the second side. Serve immediately or transfer to a platter and cover loosely with foil to keep warm. Repeat with the remaining batter, adding more butter to the skillet as needed.
6. Procedure for adding fruit to pancakes: Once the bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, scatter the surface with sliced or diced fruit, or chocolate chips, nuts, etc. Flip with a spatula and cook for 1 minute more, being careful not to burn toppings.

reviewText: Seeing as how the last Sonic game I played before this was Shadow the Hedgehog on Gamecube, this Sonic game was obviously an adjustment for me as far as game mechanics, but the changes they made to the game mechanics since StH is what made it an awesome gameplay experience for me. I love how it caters to both classic and modern Sonic fans with its two styles of gameplay. Although I prefer modern Sonic's levels, classic Sonic's levels give me a nostalgic feeling because of how similar they are to the Sega Genesis style of controlling Sonic. The modern remakes of certain levels and songs also get me nostalgic as well. And I can't forget to mention the graphics are fantastic in comparision to the Gamecube era of Sonic games. After I had beaten the storyline, the game left me with wanting more modern remakes of levels from Sonic's past. Sonic Generations is one of the best Sonic games Sega has made so far.

reviewText: Having only played classic games until buying the game, Generations is my first Modern Sonic game, and the twenty plus years in contrast between the Genesis games really showed.\nWhile modern Sonic stages were very fun, classic stages were odd. Though they played like old Sonic games, they didn't feel like old Sonic games. In short, the games expects you to use the physics instead of letting you do things your way. For example, I had a habit in older games to quickly halt myself while in a loop so I could backtrack. In this game, if you hit the brakes and try to turn around, Sonic will glitch through the loop and you'll lose a life. It's hard to express, but I hope you see my point.\nBut the game was still fun. The music was really good, and nothing beats listening to awesome songs, old and new, while dashing through stages.

reviewText:
As a massive fan of classic Sonic, I still found it hard to get into this game at times. Modern Sonic is incredibly cringe. So cringe. The cutscenes are almost unbearable. THAT SAID, I did have fun playing this game, both classic and modern levels. Not using a gamepad is going to cost you patience, though, as this port was very obviously developed for the 360. Nothing terrible.


Pros:
- Mostly fun.
- Racing Metal Sonic again is pretty sweet.
- It's almost worth the whole game's price to play a new Sky Sanctuary.
- You're able to choose what song you want to play for which level <-- Best Feature Award

Cons:
- All dialogue.
- All voice acting.
- All cutscenes.
- Buggy.
- ♥♥♥♥ physics. Classic Sonic games were fun because it was challenging to master the tough-as-nuts physics <-- Worst Feature Award
- It still ain't no Sonic 3.

Buy this game when it's on sale if you love old Sonic games.

reviewText: This is by far the best Sonic game I have played in a long time.  The graphics are amazing.  The nostalgia from the remixes all my favorite songs is great (Chemical plant zone, and City escape).  The game is short if you ignore all the extras though.  All of the bosses except the last one are top notch.  The death Egg Robot fight was good nostalgias, Shadow was fun (they put the space battle in) and the Silver Boss fight is no use.  The last one isn't bad or not fun, I just didn't like it as much as the others.  Maybe it's just because I've never been good at Super Sonic Sections.  The only 2 levels that gave me trouble were the last one and crysis city.  The last level is just too long for my taste.  This is really a problem in some of the bonus missions.  And crysis city must have been infused with the power of Sonic 06.  That level is very faithful to source material.  I got stuck on platforms, got many gameovers, had trouble locking onto enemies, had some slow down, and even got stuck on a loop once.  You can tell they really put a lot of effort into recreating crysis city.  Overall,  I would say buy this game.  Amazing music, good throwbacks to source material, plenty of nostalgia, and overall solid gameplay make this a must own for any sonic fan.  I would say you have to be good at video games to enjoy this as if you are not you will constantly run into stuff.  8.5/10.

reviewText:
2D Sonic done right.
3D Sonic done right.
Amazing reiterations of Sonic music in an orchestrial tone.
Story is dumb, but you can skip it all.
Boss fights are lacking, but still kinda fun.
Challenges to keep you busy.
Graphics done extremely well.
All the levels are rehashed directly from old Sonic games in 2D and 3D. The level design is spot on.

Sega finally make a fantastic game that left me wanting more! It's a shame that there is exclusive content on the 3DS version, because I really want to play more retro levels in the style that is Sonic Generations.

If you like Sonic, you'll love Generations.

reviewText: A wonderful celebration of one of the gaming industry's most beloved icons, Sonic Generations brings together both Sonics, classic and modern, to face a new crisis between multiple timelines. By focusing on the most important part of the series, going really fast, Sonic Generations manages to transcend the numerous problems that plagued the other Sonics in the transition to 3D. With a wonderful soundtrack, inspired updates of levels from Sonics old and new, Sonic Generations should be played by any fans of platformers.

reviewText:
Uh
Not too sure what to write here so heres a recipe for Pancakes instead

Ingredients:
1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour
3 tablespoons sugar
1 tablespoon baking powder
1/4 teaspoon salt
1/8 teaspoon freshly ground nutmeg
2 large eggs, at room temperature
1 1/4 cups milk, at room temperature
1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract
3 tablespoons unsalted butter, plus more as needed

Now to make it
1. In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, baking powder, salt, and nutmeg.
2. In another bowl, beat the eggs and then whisk in the milk and vanilla.
3. Melt the butter in a large cast iron skillet or griddle over medium heat.
4. Whisk the butter into the milk mixture. Add the wet ingredients to the flour mixture, and whisk until a thick batter is just formed
5. Keeping the skillet at medium heat, ladle about 1/4 cup of the batter onto the skillet, to make a pancake. Make 1 or 2 more pancakes, taking care to keep them evenly spaced apart. Cook, until bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, and the undersides are golden brown, about 2 minutes. Flip with a spatula and cook about 1 minute more on the second side. Serve immediately or transfer to a platter and cover loosely with foil to keep warm. Repeat with the remaining batter, adding more butter to the skillet as needed.
6. Procedure for adding fruit to pancakes: Once the bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, scatter the surface with sliced or diced fruit, or chocolate chips, nuts, etc. Flip with a spatula and cook for 1 minute more, being careful not to burn toppings.

reviewText: Sonic Generations. A title that is really good, and has a lot of replay value, but it really... understates its welcome? It has a (slightly) diverse range of remade levels from past games, and both Sonics control beautifully, but it's pretty damn short, and $50 is honestly just overpriced. But when I say replay value, I MEAN IT. It has lots of stuff to collect, including concept art for Sonic games from the past, and even MUSIC from Sonic games from the past! The levels always leave something new for every playthrough, first or not, and keep you playing over and over again. The remixes used for levels are downright AWESOME, and the bosses provide a fair challenge while not being too overly frustrating- very rarely do I ever rage-quit because of a boss. Overall, it makes its place well in the Sonic franchise, and it's an amazing 20th anniversary title. However, the story is so simplistic that it's almost bland, and it just screams missed opportunities. But it does have, yep, a modding community! You can download and play a diverse range of mods that can have new stages, characters, bosses... anything, really! Overall, it's a good game, but a bit overpriced. I recommend it to Sonic fans old and new. Heck, even if you're not a fan of Sonic, just give this game a go. You might end up loving it!

reviewText:
It's good for a Sega/Sonic game.  May be mediocre by normal standards.

-Visuals are both pretty and nostalgic
-Music has a bunch of remixes/rehashes of old songs (many of the songs werent even good to begin with)
-Voice acting is terrible as usual
-Settings and controller support arent great, kinda porty
-Gameplay is OK but has typical Sonic stuff that stops gameplay unless you have the level memorized.  And of course there is a bunch of pointless animation where you aren't actually playing.  There's also a ton of random mechanics in levels that can be both unintuitive and frustrating.  The classic version of Sonic isnt captured perfectly but it's still fun enough (I guess I could say that about the new Sonic as well).
-There's challenges that are, for the most part, not fun.
-There's skills you can buy/equip which are kinda fun I guess.

I only recommend this game if you already like Sonic.

PS:
In my opinion the pinball dlc is better realized than the whole game.  It's legitimately decent.

reviewText:
My friend listened to me sing City Escape for about an hour straight. He was a real trooper for letting me do that, despite the fact that he was surprised that I really liked the song and sang it for that long.

But for my real review, here are the reasons why I think you should buy this game:
-Great soundtrack
-Amazing level design between classic Sonic and 3D Sonic.
-Beautiful atmospheres
-Cool bosses
-Extra challenges that provide for more content in the game
-You can mod the game

I think those are reasons enough, but don't take my word for it. Go look up videos and check it out yourself before buying. Enjoy it!

reviewText:
Biggest issue for me is that Classic levels, which were the main reason for me to buy the game, are incredibly boring. They have absolutely no flow, very far from that perfect mix of speed and platforming of the Genesis classics, and they also lack uniqueness aside from a couple of gimmicks. I also experienced a weird issue with the controls of Classic Sonic: attempting the ground roll sometimes just randomly stops your momentum (instead of enhancing it) and some other times just... doesn't work.

I surprisingly found myself enjoying way more the Modern levels: overall they are fine, but I think SA2 is probably the better choice if you want that kind of gameplay (disclaimer: I'm saying this but I don't know if the PC port's any good, I played it on Dreamcast several years ago).

The extra Challenge" levels are ridiculously repetitive
date: every single one I tried basically was "repeat a portion of the level you just played with no challenge whatsoever
recommended:
but oh wait here's a totally irrelevant gimmick that'll make you think you're doing something different". Spoiler alert: you won't be doing anything different.


It's just really mediocre overall and not worth its full price
hoursPlayed: although I'd recommend it on a sale if you're a diehard Sonic fan."

reviewText:
==WARNING==
Before I start, I played through this game fully, I have completed around 2/3's of the side missions, and I have not gotten a lot of the red rings. I also used a XBOX 360 controller, so I don't know how the keyboard plays. I've played this in the past and have good knowledge about this community and past games, with that out of the way, lets get to the review!
==WARNING==

Good homage to all past sonic games, great music (as usual), brilliant level design, and great boss and rival battles, basically and argueably, the best sonic game since Ye ole days.

I've been a big fan of sonic's games, weither it would be the OG trilogy, the Storybook saga, the wii and wii u games (colours, unleashed, lost world), and even (some) the spin-offs. and I can safely say this game can hold up to the standards of the prestigous sonic installments.

The gameplay is silky smooth with eye candy graphics, Classic Sonic takes a blast to the past with ol' fashioned controls and mechanics, while Modern Sonic offers a Z-axis for all of you fancy people (me included), and new mechanics such as the lovely Boost that everyone can't keep their thumb off of your choice of key binding. Lovely gameplay just lovely.

The Music is extremely well done as always so I won't dabble a lot in this part of the review, even the remixes are enjoyable! (proceeds to sing Escape From the City WOOOO).

The Levels are well done complete with alternate paths, well placed traps and enemies, and those lovely red rings. yaaaaaaaay. With redesigns of popular places from the sonic universe such as the iconic Green Hill Zone, my only complaint is the devil stage that somehow came from the dreaded '06, (cringes) Crisis City, personally to me the hardest acts in the game, atleast it has good music! (everyone and their ears cheer!). Bosses are great, my favorite being Perfect Chaos. (I LOVE Sonic Adventure, except Big the Cat, why was he even created?!) Anyways, the bosses are great, but I can see why some people complain about them being too easy, The rival battles are one of the most enjoyable parts about this game, especially the battle with Shadow, LIVE AND LEARN. To sum it up Level design is pretty good.

The cutscenes are also well done, seeing both Sonics and the Eggmans interacting was both humorous and enjoyable. ( I need a loop of Classic Sonic trying to do the homing attack, don't ask why).

Heres a quick check list

Pros
- levels are good and well thought out (Bosses and Rivals included)
- gameplay is silky smooth
- Music is amazing as always
- graphics are eye candy, along with memorable and vibrant enviornments
- oh and a great modding community
- Get this, Side missions (Especially Modern Sonic's) ARE ACTUALLY FUN THIS TIME AROUND!
- the Collectibles are well-worth getting if you love sonic music.

Cons
- I can see why people don't like the bosses
- Crisis City
- (for me) the red rings, but they're optional
- Classic Sonic is over-SHADOWed by Modern Sonic In my opinion

I'm not giving a numeric rating so I'm ending with this

I really enjoyed this game! \m/(>.<)\m/ Rock on, or should I say, Run on!
